review: College student who doesn't do much more than write papers and do research so for that this laptop is PERFECT. Fast, sleek, easy to use. Love it!

This is a very clean looking, newer version of the previous Acer chromebook. The aluminum plate on the top is a nice touch and the battery lasts a long time like other chromebooks. For the price, this computer is a steal! I started using chromebooks a year and a half ago for online school and have never looked back. I use my windows laptop for music and video production (because those are some of the only things you can't do on a chromebook) and now utilize ChromeOS for everything else. Word processing with Google Docs, photo editing with pixlr.com, and hosts of other applications are available. Sometimes it is a bit of a challenge to find the right apps to use as an alternative to Windows, but if you really wanted to you can just put a linux distro on there with crouton. Super easy.

The screen is very bright on this one and the keyboard is a standard chromebook one. I don't like the touchpad very much and my Samsung Chrombook 2 has a better one, so that would be the only downside. Good color, aesthetics, and usability!
the perfect notebook for internet work .. I have bought three now ..  I will buy more but they keep raising the price ..  150 .. 139. and now 179 ..

Only complaint would be the track pad can be a little tricky with trying to click on something. But for all the other pros and the price of the computer I wouldn't take off a star. This is the perfect laptop and couldn't of expected more for the price. Make sure you know what you're buying and you won't be disappointed.

Perfect little device for casual web browsing, when your tablet leaves you wanting a keyboard and mouse. A nice upgrade to the CB3-111, namely the IPS display. Handles my 3-5 tabs and 4 extensions with ease.

This is my first Chromebook and I am very happy with it. One thing I've found with this one that works better than others is the track pad. Some others that I've used, including the last iteration of the Acer 11, were frustrating to use and not responsive; but the track pad included with this one is great.

The keyboard is fine. you don' get outstanding feedback but it's good enough for me.

The design is really nice including the textured top.

The screen, even though not the highest resolution, looks great.

For $180, this Chromebook meets all expectations and then some.
An okay cheapo computer. My previous acer broke after three years, so I guess this one will live approximately such an time and age

I want to give a brief background of where Im coming from and what I think about the new Acer Chromebook 11.  In the past I have owned a Thinkpad laptop, a Dell notebook with a touchscreen and pen, and a couple of tower desktop computers.  I have also owned two Android devices.  These days I mostly use an Ipad for web browsing and apps, and a desktop for word processing, printing, Microsoft office needs, the occasional game, etc.  I needed something at my work that was small and light and did not need a lot of computing power.  I didn't want to spend much money.  After hearing about Chromebooks for a while, I did as much research as I could and decided a Chromebook fit the bill.
Amazon has a ton of Chromebooks, and I was about to buy the Chromebook 11 from last year, then found an article that was 1 day old saying that Acer had just released their new 2016 version of the 2 GB Chromebook 11.  They explained that this one was built to be quite durable with an aluminum lid, and that it would feature an IPS screen, for only $179.  They said a 4 GB version was bound to be released soon, and I wish it were available, but I figured 2 GB is adequate for my needs.  I followed the link to Amazon, and found it here.

First impressions:

Build quality  It is not as tightly put together as say a tablet or a high end laptop, but it feels very well made.  The screen articulates well and the lid feels sturdy.  The keyboard has a nice feel to it, much better than my Logitech for my iPad, and Id say just about as good as any laptop Ive used.  It does have a strip of plastic between the track-pad and the space bard which is somewhat flimsy, though, and when I press down with moderate pressure, the whole middle of the keyboard flexes.  Overall, though, I am impressed, especially for $179.  Haven't dropped it yet, but I think it would survive.

Ergonomics  The keyboard feels like a full size; the volume and power buttons are in a good place, and the keyboard is comfortable to type on.  The trackpad is larger than Im used to and even the fastest setting doesnt feel fast enough for me as I usually have to lift my finger off the trackpad to get from one side of the screen to the other.  I like the no buttons choice of the trackpad though, and how the whole pad just clicks down if you feel you need a click.  The SIZE and WEIGHT are incredible!  I guess most chrome books are this way, but I am amazed.  It feels lightweight but not cheap.  The keys are not backlit.  Webcam is stationary, and I doubt I will ever use this with Facetime on the ipad / iphone so simple and easy.  Maybe they could do a version without this and drop another $20?

Display  The display looks very bright, crisp; just what youd expect from an IPS screen.  Now if I can only manage to stop poking it with my touch-screen trained fingers, I expect it to last.  The fact that it is not a touch-screen makes this feel more like a laptop to me.

Color   It looks good in white casing with black keys (kind of like a piano), but white would not be my first choice due to the inevitability to show dirt and oil after a while.  Also the exterior it textured, which feels cool, but will probably attract more dirt that way.

Sound -- Volume is pretty loud.  Not sure the decibels, but is is louder than an laptop, phone, or tablet I've had.  I was surprised to hear what sounded like stereo Left and Right sound coming from a video, when I looked on the bottom and noticed it had two speakers.  Only realistic improvement would be if they could have mounted the speakers on the front instead of the bottom.  I could imagine it getting muffled if on a blanket or other soft surface.  But the sound exceeded my expectations for the price for sure.

Software  having no background in Chrome OS, I find this software simple and easy to understand.  You cant really screw it up.  Somewhat disappointed with the app store.  Does not seem like a lot of high quality apps to pick from, but that is coming from an apple user (and previously android).  UPDATE: the "OK Google" feature which allows voice searches and commands was not working.  I spent an hour on a help chat with google, and they couldn't determine the problem, but finally asked me to "Powerwash" the machine, essentially wiping it and returning it back to factory state.  It took about 2 minutes to powerwash and set it up again, and the "OK Google" feature miraculously worked again.  I have had no other OS issues.

Speed  The computer starts almost as instantly as a phone.  Clicking on anything gives no lag.  It is snappy, and I think it will stay that way.  Youtube streams beautifully.  Webpages load fast.  If they had had the 4 GB version, I would have considered it, but 2 GB is not too slow for me right now.

Value  Cant believe it was only $179.  Great job Acer, and great job Amazon for getting it to me in a day and a half with Prime.
I will make sure to update as I use it more, and if my opinion changes.

The Acer Chromebook 11 is probably my pick now for sub $200 Chromebooks. The reason is that it has the nicest display (IPS) you'll see at this price point on any platform from any brand. This is not a full HD display but rather a lower resolution 1366x768 display. Nevertheless it looks much better than the TN panels you'll see on other similarly priced devices. It's powered by last year's Intel N2840 Celeron processor at 2.16ghz and has 2 gigabytes of RAM and 16 gigabytes of on board storage. The Acer Chromebook 11's SD card slot does sit flush to the side of the computer though, so it does provide some opportunities for expanded storage. Performance is decent for basic web browsing tasks and on par with other devices from Acer and others at this $180 price point. The hardware overall is well constructed and it's very comfortable to type on. My only gripe is with its trackpad that requires a little too much of a push to register clicks. This is an exceptional value for $179. I do suggest that you watch my ChromeOS 101 video to learn more about what Chromebooks are and what they are not:

This laptop cost me only $99 for the 2 GB RAM 16 GB MMC version on Black Friday and it's the cheapest, functional and well-built computer I've ever seen. At first I bought it to do simple tasks while sending my main laptop to technical support but then I decided to install a second operating system: Gallium OS, a Linux distro specially designed for Chromebooks since it's impossible to boot Windows in this laptop. Gallium was very easy to install and the performance is incredible, I love how it manages the system resources except the battery that goes from 9 hours in Chrome OS to 6-7 hours in Gallium OS, but it's not a big deal, I can do most of the things I did in Windows. In fact, I've been working 8 hours a day from Monday to Friday during the last 2 months with this little warrior and I feel I can't ask for more. In addition I was able kept Chrome OS with dual boot but I rarely use it. The Acer is great for entertaining too, last night I saw a movie through the HDMI port but the TV sounded very low and the laptop speakers were loud enough to fill our living room. This is the best purchase I've ever made.

The Good:
This Chromebook is incredibly light and has a solid 9 hours worth of battery. If you are looking for a portable web-browsing machine, this is a solid choice. It can connect to both my 2.4G and 5G wireless networks, has easy Bluetooth pairing capabilities, and a lot of options to customize many aspects of the device. The power-on time is absolutely amazing! From the moment of pressing the power button, the unit takes less than 15 seconds to get you to the login screen.

The OK:
With more and more services moving to cloud-based offerings, we use our web browser to access many of these offerings instead of installing applications that run locally on your computer. For things like Gmail, Amazon Video, etc this isn't uncommon and feels normal. For other apps (some in competition with Amazon services so I will refrain from naming them here :) ), this is a little more awkward, especially with some of the web apps being less feature-rich than their locally-installed counterparts. With this Chromebook, almost everything opens in the Chrome browser. Even "apps" installed from the store are often just links to the app's web interface. There are a few exceptions, but they are an exception, not the standard. As a general statement, this is workable. Robust web interfaces have done a great job at minimizing the awkwardness of this, but it's just something to note about how this works differently than a laptop. One other notable item that's not good or bad, just different, is there is no right-click option on the touchpad. In order to right-click on anything (such as to open a link in a new tab in Chrome), you have to press the Alt key at the same time you click the touchpad. That is not intuitive or apparent, so it took some a little web searching to find out how to do it. Once you know, you can adapt, but again, just a difference.

The Ugly
Because this unit is not able to use the Android app store, there is a VERY limited selection of apps. I use IFTTT on my cell phone for a variety of automated tasks (if you aren't familiar with the app, you should check it out!), however there is no official app or extension that can be used for this Chromebook. This device uses the Chrome Web Store, which is sorely lacking in offerings. There is no Uber or Lyft apps, as other quick examples.

All that said, as long as you know what to expect from this device and are ok with the use cases, it's pretty solid. I use mine for streaming movies to my Chromecast from Amazon Video, Plex, and YouTube with no lag or choppiness. I also use it a lot for web browsing, be it shopping, research, or fantasy football.  For the price (got mine on sale over the holidays for less than it's listed as of 3-11-2018), it's a decent unit..just know what you are getting into and don't assume this is a really cheap laptop...it's not.

Cons:  Speakers are loud and when reached to the highest volume, the sound would get grainy. The track-pad can easily get messy, so clean it. Not as much more things to do with the laptop, but for 160 dollars what do you expect?

Pros
- Extremely affordable
- Display is actually quite nice
- The plastic cover of the laptop is definitely something I didn't expect
- Long battery life (6-8 hours at a time)
Cons
- This Chromebook cannot handle above 720p videos without substantially losing frames (fps)
- Chromebook cannot handle too many tabs open at the same time (it will literally kill previous tabs to have the cpu keep up with your activity)

The only really disappointing about this Chromebook specifically is the fact that the cpu cannot handle more than four moderately-intensive tabs running at the same time in the background. That's the reason why I marked off a star, as I expected a little more from the cpu, but all-in-all, what this laptop has is great value. If you are looking for value, then this should be your "go-to"
Just keep in mind that Chrome OS is a machine built for web browsing- and not much else

Got this model a year ago. My 07 macbook pro was in need of replacement, and while I am an Mac person (I LOATHE Windows),  I did not want the hefty Apple price tag. Enter Chromebook. After doing some research, it sounded like a Chromebook would be perfect for my needs - everything I needed to do for work was dependent on online programs rather than software and my personal use was just for the basics of email/social media /web browsing.

I chose this model because I trusted Acer and also because I loved the small size and I couldn't help but notice there was something kind of macbook mini-esque about it...... Perfect for me to take wherever I go! My only complaint is the white does get dirty for me as its usually either in a backpack or behind the counter of a busy bar - but other than that, this thing is perfect!

Although I was a little scared to get a laptop that was under $200, all i really needed it for was to edit documents for work, manage our online payment processor, and send emails to customers. For documents It took a little figuring out, but with Word and Xcel online, coupled with DropBox or OneDrive, this thing turned out to be a breeze to use for simple work documents I was editing daily. Also, the battery lasts forever! I don't even bring the charger with me to work!

It's been used at least 5 days a week for the past year and it has more than exceeded the value of $200. This little laptop is fantastic. If you have simple needs and want portability and reliability buy this laptop. Over all this Acer Chromebook has exceeded my expectations. I would give this 10 stars if I could!

While knowing it's not the top of the line with every feature available, I have no complaints. People newly purchasing this might want to check which version of Chrome is running, as the one I received was running a much outdated version and I had to manually update the OS by reinstalling (a very easy task a quick google search will have you on your way in minutes) due probably to outdated firmware, but nonetheless a rather simple process if needed. All other things aside, there's not a lot to say except it lives up to what it claims: long battery life, average display, the keyboard is responsive and I actually find it quite quick to type on compared to my other computers. The only thing I wish I'd done was do more research beforehand as to which models (rather than just version of Chrome) allowed the Android app Play Store, but depending on your needs that might not be an issue. If the main thing you want to be able to do is quickly and efficiently browse the web with a reliable and long lasting (and light!) platform, you won't be disappointed.

I just got this Chromebook a couple of weeks ago on Cyber Monday on sale for $100. To say I'm satisfied is an understatement. This particular Chromebook is just extraordinary. The keyboard feels great and just has a very high-quality feel to it. The ISP screen looks fantastic, perhaps looking even better than my 20 inch monitor hooked up to my Windows desktop. And the touchpad is incredibly responsive and a pleasure to use. Overall the entire machine just feels high quality and functions spectacularly.

Moreover, one of the things I especially love about this machine and Chromebooks in general, is the fact that it goes instantly on, instantly off, and comes out of sleep instantly. This stands in direct contrast to My Windows desktop which would sometimes takes 10 minutes before I can get online and sometimes forces me to wait 3 to 5 minutes for it to just shut off.

Web browsing is like lightning. I feel like I have a different internet provider using this machine. With My Windows desktop websites that take 30 seconds, 1 minute, or perhaps even lock up my computer entirely open up instantly on this Chromebook. And this is using a WiFi connection that is essentially in the corner of my basement. And yet the web speeds are incredible and the connection is beyond stable.

I also love the fact that with this machine as is the case with all Chromebooks, you no longer have to worry about installing an antivirus, or getting viruses, or getting your Windows updates. It's essentially maintenance-free.

Also, as compared to my Windows computers where the performance seems they get slower and slower with each passing week this machine has not slowed down at all. It is just as fast today as the day I got it.

One final thought for anyone concerned about the size of the screen. I was a bit concerned that the screen might be too small but it hasn't proven to be an issue at all. Three steps I do easily take care of that problem. I set the font size to large. I set the web pages to load full screen. And I make the default setting of the zoom feature 125%. Some websites I've even zoomed to 175 or 200% and they still look perfectly fine to read. You can easily change the zoom Factor by simply pressing Ctrl +, or control minus.

Overall, I am just in love with the whole Chromebook concept, and this Chromebook in particular is nothing short of fantastic. I couldn't recommend it any more highly.

Again, if you're looking for a laptop for yourself or your kid for school or to write papers and browse facebook and watch youtube, this laptop is perfect for that.

So I'm going to start by saying this is the best Chromebook under 200 dollars. Nice screen, lightweight, great battery life.  With that being said it is also one of the most limited, no playstore support as of December 2017.

The chrome web store doesn't have much to offer in terms of apps you would need for basic internet computing. It's fine for browsing the web and using Google web apps but in terms of file support it's horrible. No support for torrents, magnets or file compression outside of a limited zip file tool.

I understand that this is a web based laptop but things that have been standard for over 10 years are completely ignored. I can get more done on a low level Android tablet then I can on this laptop and it is simply because google hasn't brought the playstore to this platform yet.

Another plus side it's easy to ditch chrome os and install a proper version of linux.

ABSOLUTELY LOVE IT! This is not one of the latest Chromebook models, but it is certainly one of the best. The IPS screen is simply gorgeous! I have a Windows laptop costing about five times as much and this screen is definitely better. The keyboard is another highlight for me. Many laptop keyboards have keys that are too "squishy" with too much travel and not enough resistance. This one is just right. It is also VERY light and yet sturdily built, with an attractive patterned aluminum top cover. Battery life is another wonderful feature - if you need a machine that lasts the entire work day or school day, you won't be disappointed. I easily get around 9 hours, with the screen at about 75% brightness, which is still very bright. Also has a full-size SD card slot, which is nice since I had several camera cards sitting around. As some Chromebooks have lately advanced (strayed?) from the original standards, adding more power, size, weight and expense, I am happy that this model is a prime example of Google's original intent: Secure, inexpensive, sturdy and extremely mobile, with quick access to online content and enough computing power to satisfy the daily needs of nearly all users. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED.

You can do MS Word, Excel, etc., using the Chrome Store app, or just go directly to Office365, where you can edit and save work (for free). As for Android Apps, this model is on the list to integrate the Google Play store. Am expecting it soon. Google has been SLOWLY working their way through each model listed.

P.S. For those complaining that Chromebooks don't do certain things, you'll find that they do if you just search for Chromebook help. You only need to learn a few new keyboard shortcuts.

Comments and feedback specific to Chrome OS and intended for Child / School use.

The parental control on Chromebook would not allow users to be locked down based on age range.  Users would need to login using their own gmail account in order to use Apps.  Which means, you as the parent cannot control the content, search, and sites that your child can access.

There is a "Supervised" account that can be used but then they will not be able to use Apps downloaded from Google Play.  Some of the school assignments require the downloading of Apps available on iOS or Android, PC.

The "Supervised" account also does not have an age range setting which would restrict "inappropriate" content.  You have to specify each individual website domain.

Reading the Google support boards, this seems to be case since 2014 and does not appear any advancement has been made to this function.  I did read you can use a Google Family to set up accounts for child under 13 but that is just too complicated for a function available on most PC and security software.

Do yourself a favor by Powerwashing this device before use.
For some unknown reason, I found my brand new laptop is sluggish and does not response well. I had the Acer c720 to compare with so I know how fast it should be. After trying to configure the settings, I gave up. My final solution is a powerwash before getting ready to return the laptop. Sweet, the laptop feels a lot faster and responsive. In case you don't know how to powerwash:
1. Click on the right bottom where your time, notification
2. Click on the settings icon near bottom left on that box
3. Scroll down to bottom, hit "Advanced"
4. Scroll down to bottom again, hit "Powerwash" and follow it on.
5. Wait then enjoy your chromebook again.

I LOVE these Chromebooks! I purchased 2 of these Chromebooks for my kids to use and now my entire family uses them. I have Prime so shipping is always fast and they were packaged safely and well. As for speed a Chromebook can NOT be beaten, especially for the price! If you are unfamiliar with Chrome OS I will attempt to explain a few of the differences between this and a 'regular' laptop- I am not a techie so please excuse the 'lay-speak'. First off- Chromebooks are cloud based, which means all updates are done 'in the cloud' without you having to do anything at all and without interrupting your computer time. Also viruses are not an issue with cloud based OS which is GREAT if you have kids and teens who want to download every new game and mod they see! You don't need to pay for virus protection because you can't download anything into the hard-drive. You CAN download pictures and videos into your files so you can save your important stuff. Also because it's cloud based you can access your photos anywhere you can log into your Chrome account. These Chromebooks stream videos without lag even with multiple pages open. I've NEVER had lag. They do not have optical drives so you can't watch DVD's but with Hulu and Netflix and Amazon Video that has never been an issue for us. I've heard people complain about the keyboard not having caps lock or other things they are used to but it is VERY easy to change your keyboard to your liking- for example, I have never used the built in 'search' button so I changed it to be my 'caps lock'. All you need to do is look up "how to change a chromebook keyboard' or something similar and  you will find easy to follow instructions. Chromebooks also have a built in word program that is compatible with Microsoft Word and easily converts. My children's school uses it for all homework assignments and it is quite intuitive, more so than Word for me. Sorry about the rambling and the length of this review but I just can't say enough good things about these Chromebooks! If you are on the fence take the plunge and BUY A CHROMEBOOK!! Acer are the best in my opinion!! I plan on buying at least one more of these for Christmas this year, possibly two!

If you want a cheap chromebook for basic web browsing and using google drive and apps, I don't know how you could do better.  Durable case, fantastic battery life, and I've never had issues with crashing, this thing has been an awesome workhorse for me.

I use the laptop for college, mostly google sheets and some google docs. I can use the word app off the app store if I wanted that format. I access Pearson MyMathLab with the laptop to do work. Opening a 1200 page calculus PDF file will lag ONLY when you use the scroll function on the right side to skip over 50 pages, but using bookmark function doesn't lag at all. For any CAD work and gaming I have a home PC, for everything else this is perfect. Also has performed decent for programming, but usually these classes provide you a computer to work on in-class which is much better.

A tip, if you buy it and want to drag and drop stuff, go into settings > manage accessibility features > mouse and touchpad settings >  turn ON tap to drag

P.S. The OS has never crashed for me, so remember to turn it off occasionally and restart or you might get funky issues.

Thank you for ruining a special day because you don't look at the items that get returned. When I returned it, I included the previous slip too. Hopefully no one gives a gift with 2 return labels.

My job has put up too many firewalls and internet restrictions on the corporate laptop so I decided to buy something inexpensive to take to work with me (I'm a field auditor and I travel to various locations).  I found this Chromebook for under $200 and I thought it would be perfect to check personal emails, pay bills, online shopping, the usual stuff while away from home.  At first I really liked the Chromebook.  It took some adjustments to get accustom to Google Sheets and Docs instead of the Microsoft Office Suite products I have used all my life.  The Chrome browser took some getting used to as I have been a Firefox user for a long time.  But lately I have really started getting frustrated with the Chromebook.  It started when I discovered there is no driver available for my Epson printer to work with the Chromebook.  It is just a standard, run-of-the-mill Epson printer.  I had to use a cloud service to be able to print.  But it is print only, I can no longer scan.  That really sucks.  Another issue, I have started looking for another house to buy and as I am scrolling through houses on Zillow the Chromebook doesn't seem to work well with that website.  It will often "stall out" and the refresh circle keeps spinning which means I have to close out the window and start over again.  I really don't try to do anything unusual with the laptop.  I'm not asking it to run heavy graphics, I don't do any downloading, just the typical websites everyone uses.  This machine really lacks in performance.

This is the perfect little laptop. I got it for my ten-year-old and is exactly what I was looking for. Excellent price, good product.  I will point out that it is not compatible with Microsoft.

This chromebook was a nightmare to actually get functioning.  When I first logged into my account, it set off a continuous crashing cycle that made it impossible to do anything.  Then, because guest logins weren't given admin privileges, even though I could somewhat access the internet and some chrome features, I couldn't actually change anything.

Based on some online discussion threads, I powerwashed the chromebook (reset it completely to the starting conditions) and created a new google login to try to access admin settings.  But checking for updates to Chrome OS showed that a terribly out-of-date version of the OS was allegedly up to date.  And no amount of changing around my sync settings or extensions fixed the issue.

I finally got Acer support, and they informed me I would need to use the Chrome recovery process, where I would create a new OS install file on a flash drive and use it to manually force an updated version onto my machine.  But, of course, my Chromebook by default didn't recognize my first USB stick because it registered as an external hard drive rather than removable storage!  So after spending 2 hours attempting to get the flash drive to work, I finally switched to a second flash drive and it finally worked.

At this point I have wasted ~5 hours attempting to get even minimal functionality out of this device which is supposed to be reputed for its simplicity and streamlined user experience.

I would recommend looking for a different option if you want a chromebook that's usable out of the box.
Had for 1 week before the mouse touchpad stopped working. Now my daughter needs it for schoolwork and i have to return and purchase a new one.

I got a virus on my Chromebook three days after I purchased it. The Chromebook specifically says that it is already protected and I quote "Chrome OS does not get viruses, malware or ransomware because it doesn't let them download or run." Well, obviously that is not true. My whole screen went red and that annoying recording came on (you know what i'm talking about if you have ever gotten a virus) and you can't shut it off. It was flashing and blinking. I ended up having to call support and have them instruct me on how to get rid of the blinking screen. Super annoying and if it happens again I'm returning my Chromebook.

I thought that since I have used Google Chrome as my browser for a few years that I would love this computer. I like the small size and I obviously love using Chrome. There are some unpleasant quirks.
*There is no delete button. You have to use the arrow back then backspace to delete one letter in a sentence. That can actually be good. It makes it easy to write and correct.
*There is no right click function. I haven't learned how to copy and paste yet. I'm sure that there is a way to do that.
*Pages crash but reload quickly. Sometimes I have to click the re-load button.
I didn't think that the small memory would be a problem, but it is a problem.
I will probably be updating this review since I have had this Chromebook for just a few hours.
I've been reading other reviews and there is one issue that others had that I don't have with this model of the Acer Chromebook. The wire is different from the photos that I have looked at. Acer must have listened to the complaints.
UPDATE: if you purchase a wireless mouse, you will gain the right click function. The computer is still unstable. Pages have to be reloaded frequently.
UPDATE: 1-4-18 I think that the latest update to Chrome has this little computer running more quickly, I actually added a star because it is working much better than my Windows laptop. It had been my favorite until now.
UPDATE: 8-16-18 I had this for one year and it quit.

Go read Souther's 5 Star Review.  I read it, and purchased mine.  I agree with everything in Souther's review.  This little Acer  is everything I need and more. I am a teacher, university student, blogger, online shopper, and spend a normal time on social media.  I have watched Chromebooks being used in classrooms for a few years, and see how they are far superior to iPads in class.
Thee speed of this computer and capacity of it's operating system make. it comparable to any laptop for my computing needs.
It takes about two minutes to plug in and go.  It is lightweight, so great for laptop use, since my other was heavy and hot.
I prefer this to an iPad, laptop or cellphone. For desk work in a restaurant this is perfect.  There are times I still prefer a desktop computer, but I will not ever have another desktop at home.  This is sufficient!
It has a drive insert for your WORD docs and other storage and opens them immediately.  You do not need to add any other software.
Everything is linked to your google account and google drive.  Since I have already been using Google Drive for all my documents and slide shows, I did not have to relearn anything.  All storage is in the cloud, but you can store onto an external jump drive.  If you are totally committed to the Microsoft name, and Microsoft Office Suite, you will need to learn to use Google.
I should have bought this a long time ago!  I'm a convert!

1 month update:  I LOVE MY CHROMEBOOK!  I prefer it to my handheld when I'm at home due to it's large, clear screen, light weight and cool unit, and ease of keyboard.

There is a learning curve on how to use the WORD app that is available for free.  Also for opening and editing WORD docs that are on a hard drive.  Since I was already familiar with the GoogleDocs platform, I'm getting used to the switch, BUT there is a learning curve, and can be frustrating, if you need something fast.  Still giving it 5 STARS. One of the best electronic purchases in my life.

5 month update.  I STILL love my Chromebook.  I love how light it is, and that I can shove it quickly and easily into my purse and not feel like I'm lugging a traditional laptop around.
I am going to downgrade my original review to 4 stars because it is not able to handle the type of work I am doing right now for my job.
As a teacher, I am researching a lot of pdf's and student worksheets to download and print.
Downloading and printing from the web is more complicated and time consuming on my Chromebook, than on a laptop.
I don't like how the Chromebook handles downloads in a download file.  It requires me to save it before printing, and I really don't want to save it.  Other than that, I have played some simple online games, and it works super well for these.

When I am web browsing, it loads up my tabs on top so I end up having so many tabs open, until it finally maxes out.  It's just easier to turn it off and start fresh, than to attempt to open each tab to close it.

Still the best deal for your daily internet, social media, word processing, and document storage and retrieval available.  Still happy with it.

However, after about a year of use I noticed that the wifi-range was *significantly* reduced, and performance began to worsen to the point that there would be sudden freezes/crashes. I love this thing, but I'm afraid it doesn't last long.

Good

I bought this for the touch screen because my typical carry-around device is a Kindle Fire tablet, and since I was looking for another portable device with a little more functionality, like a physical keyboard, the Acer checked all the right boxes.  I bought the Amazon basics neoprene sleeve and now this thing goes with me everywhere, and now more often than not I use it at home for basic web tasks and Google docs.  In fact, since I have purchased this device I have migrated almost everything of value to Google Drive, and i am about a month away from being done with MSFT forever.  I might prefer a larger screen, but that would impact portability, and even though my home work station is 2X "27" ASUS monitors with a 32" Samsung side-car I can still get a lot done on this machine, mainly because the screen is large enough to see a full browser and because touch allows me to quickly resize windows in a way I can't do on my monitors.

My only complaint is the power cord, it's 90 degree 2-3mm thing that automatically makes the cord harder to deal with because it wants to rotate, and whenever it's plugged in and my dog walks by I can see how easy it would be for that thing to just snap off, or yank the computer to the ground whereas a straight plug would just release without damage.  Another problem is that the bend creates kinks, making the jack want to rotate, and when it does it impinges on BOTH USB ports on the left side.  I can understand why they may need to put the power supply port in that location to save cost, but the 90 degree bend as opposed to a straight pin just seems like a design flaw.  I suppose there is another power supply available you can buy to replace this, and maybe they already fixed it, but as it stinks.

I love my Acer Chromebook! I bought it so I could keep up with my students who all have similar Chromebooks. It has been wonderful to use with Google Classroom and all of the Google office products we use in my English classes. I have also been able to learn some cool shortcuts and tricks from my students and show them a few too.

If given the choice, I would rather use my Chromebook than any other device I own: laptop or Ipad. It is so fast and works way better with all of the Google tools out there. I was worried about not being able to work off-line, but you can use many Google products off-line, like Docs.

There atre some great extensions out there for educators and they all help me to comment and assess my students' work. I have found that to be more meaningful for my students and their progress in class.

The only downside to my Chromebook is that it does not run Java. Unfortunately, my online gradebook uses Java and I have to do that on a laptop.  But, since I use Classroom to grade my students' work, I can use both devices and get it done quickly.

Bought it about 1.5 years ago.  Loved it at first.  Fast, light, it was a joy to surf the web.  If that's ALL you want to do, you'll love it.

I mostly use this just to web browse, but occasionally I need it to do other things.  Here's where the problems begin.

1. Remote access. Loved this feature where I could use the chromebook to access my regular computer. Except it caused my chromebook to freeze REPEATEDLY.  Even when I wasn't using remote access.  That was the first time I experienced freezing (but not the last) and happened very early on.  I no longer use the remote access feature, although the chromebook still freezes (read on).

2.  Playing Pandora causes freezing.  So I don't visit the Pandora site anymore.

3. Google Drive causes freezing, particularly Google Sheets.

Are you noticing a trend? Almost everything causes this thing to freeze!  I don't mean it freezes every single time I use the above, but quite often.  And sometimes I'm not using any of the above and it still freezes!  Sometimes certain webpages make it freeze.

Latest problem which just started happening a few days ago:  I can't print!  Had no problem attaching a cloud HP printer and have used this baby to print hundreds of times.  Suddenly, page previews will not load when hitting the Print command.  And because the previews won't load, the pages print blank.

Even before the above started happening, I would get this stupid popup about adding a cloud printer every time I went to print something.  I already have a cloud printer!  Nevertheless, every single freaking time, a popup window would open when I wanted to print, which I would then have to close before it proceeded to print.

This thing is getting more and more useless.  Really starting to hate it.  Definitely not worth the price and would not recommend.

I've had my Chromebook for about a year now and have waited to write this review until I've had a chance to get to know it a little bit. I love that my Chromebook feels like my "Google Drive machine". During senior year in college, I've really gotten some great use out of this computer. I've made a pros and cons list below.

Pros:
Battery life - It lasts longer than any other laptop I've used or my friends/family have used
Light weight - Fits perfectly into my backpack and I'm able to carry it around all day without any problems
Durability - I've dropped this a couple times (from short distances (1-2 feet) and can recognize no issues or cosmetic problems

Cons:
Performance - Sometimes, I can't have more than 2 tabs open before the computer locks up and shuts itself down. It is, without a doubt, the most maddening issued I've experienced with this computer.
Screen - The display of the screen feels harsh, even with the brightness turned down. I feel like my eyes strain too much when reading off of it.

Overall, this Chomebook just feels "okay" to me. It certainly does the job and allows me to edit any of my Google docs and use the internet. However, with the glaring performance issue of frequently crashing (usually at least once every time I use the computer), I will not be a repeat customer of the Chromebook. That isn't to say it's trash - I will certainly still be using it until it becomes no longer necessary to or obsolete. And, for the money, it's a great buy. It's just that I didn't expect it to be so sluggish when using the internet and, in the future, I'd like something that could handle a little more.
Have had this unit for a little over a year, and it's still going strong. No problems and no complaints.
It worked for two months. The screen stopped working. I sent it off for repair and it was returned (still broken) and was told it was out of warranty. I bought it 2 months ago. I feel ripped off.

After spilling water on my previous laptop, I began my search for an affordable simple laptop that I could use to write up documents, surf the web, and stream music and Netflix. So far this laptop has done a pretty great job of doing just that, although it isn't perfect.

The Pros:
-Even with my slower internet connection the Acer Chromebook is very quick to load web pages or videos
-The keyboard is a regular size (minus the number pad) and feels very nice to type on. The keys are sensitive, but not too sensitive.
-I specifically wanted a Chromebook to avoid Windows and Mac, so if that's what you're looking for this will be great.
-The battery life is excellent
-It's lightweight and feels sturdy (although I haven't dropped it or spilled anything on it yet)

The Cons:
-About once a day the computer freezes and shuts down all my tabs. It's easy to restore and I've tried to troubleshoot some things, but it still struggles at least once a day, which is incredibly annoying.
-It took me a bit to realize that in place of the caps lock is a search tool, you can change this so it stays a caps lock, but it confused me at first.

My only complaint really about this computer is the constant freezing, but I wonder if I just have a dud or it was beaten around a little during transport. Hard to say. Overall, I would definitely recommend if you need an affordable, but good laptop.

$170, it sounds too good to be true? That's because it is. I live in Chicago and unfortunately, my Mac Book Pro was stolen. I did my research and decided to purchase this to get by in the meantime. I thought it would be perfect since I work a ton out of Google Drive and Gmail. Well despite feeling great physically, the keyboard is awesome...and looking great, the screen's resolution is bright and crisp, that's about where the pluses end. I don't know what these other people are reviewing but I think we are talking about different things. This thing was designed for one thing, internet browsing. And it fails, all day every day. It's no use opening more than five tabs, it can't handle it, especially if one of those tabs contains video or audio. I am constantly holding down the power button. I thought these days of my life were over but I guess not.

In this case, you get what you pay for. And it's WAY too good to be true. I find myself pulling out my phone to look something up quicker than whenever it freezes on what I was googling. Something tells me waiting and saving for my next Mac is going to be a lot of extra pain while I am stuck using this device.

I've had this Chromebook for a few months, and it does exactly what I need it to do.  It starts up fast, all the components work as expected, the battery life is great, and it is incredibly durable and transportable.  The camera and sound are surprisingly good. It does struggle to run some basic apps or multiple browsing tabs.  Facebook and Hulu together, for example, shuts it right down.  Skype shuts down a lot.  But that's in the nature of the machine.  You just take one second to restart (Chrome will remember which tabs you had open) and don't run too many programs at once.  Be aware that Chromebook apps are often limited in scope at this time.  You may be surprised at which basic functions are tricky, such as recording a video or cropping a picture.  But if you're creative and know how to read a support forum, you'll figure it out.  If you travel a lot, worry about having an expensive computer due to a lot of rough handling, and love Google Drive, this is a great option at an unbeatable price.  It does handle multiple Google accounts just fine.

I originally bought a Chromebook to compliment my desktop setup. When I'm home, I use my desktop to do computationally heavy tasks. When I'm out and about, I use the Chromebook for productivity tasks (taking notes, light journalism, emails, etc.). When I need the extra horsepower, I can stream my desktop over to my Chromebook. Sounds neat, except for the fact that THIS DAMN THING CAN'T EVEN KEEP 7 TABS OPEN WITHOUT STUTTERING AND OCCASIONALLY CRASHING. Really Acer? I get it, this is a budget web machine, it's not meant to do heavy workloads. But WHY ON EARTH would you release a web machine that can't even support a handful of pinned email tabs, a few google searches, Spotify, and Google Docs. I don't remember older Chromebooks having an issue this severe.

In fact, I shouldn't be having to wait through stutters while typing this review. If you're a student or a slightly heavy internet user, find something more powerful. The 30 second crashes aren't worth it.

Last year I bought this exact same Chromebook for my 82 year old mother. It is ideal for her to check email, FB, and play games. She loved it so much, we just bought this one for an even older friend. The set-up of this machine is very simple and using it is so simple an octogenarian can use it without trouble. It is very light and small, making it perfectly portable for them when they go cruising. For this type of user, this device is perfect.

The only drawback is that you can only print to printers that have google print service. Otherwise, there is no print function.

I'm not sure why this particular model doesn't have any reviews. I'm assuming it's because people usually go with the 2gb model. Well, I tried that 2gb model and I lovingly refer to it as "the grandma model." It's fine for very basic internet surfing, but I found it to be sluggish compared to this 4gb one. I immediately returned the 2gb model after two days of using for this 4gb one. After a week of using this model, I can easily say that I love it.

My main purpose for getting a chromebook was to use writerduet, a screenwriting program, on it. When I downloaded the writerduet extension on the 2gb, I found it took quite a while for it to load. If I had a couple of tabs open and tried to open the writerduet extension as well, I felt the experience was quite sluggish. On this 4gb model, I felt the loading time for the extension was cut in half. Maybe more! I can have a couple of tabs open along with the writerduet extension and not experience any lag. It's great.

Even if you're not looking to use that particular extension, I'm sure this chromebook will suit your needs if you're planning to do some multitasking on it. I'd highly recommend it to anyone looking for a cheap means to go online and use browser based software.

The battery life is great. Most of the information online promise 9 hours of battery life, which you do get, but if you don't stream videos and just do word processing and surfing, you can definitely pump out around 12 hours of battery life. It's very impressive. the screen isn't the most miraculous display you'll lay your eyes on, but it's very much serviceable. I enjoy using it for youtube, netflix, and hulu (oh, and amazon streaming, too. Sorry, amazon.) The build of the chromebook is very nice. It's very lightweight and portable. That was definitely a plus for me because I hate lugging around my 15" windows laptop. It looks great and the keys do not feel mushy like on other models I've checked out. I can see myself typing on this one for hours.

Just be sure you know what you're getting into when getting a chromebook. There are some great videos on youtube explaining what a chromebook is compared to a mac and pc. If you know what you're getting into, this is definitely a solid purchase.
Love the Acer chrome book. So simple and easy to use.

ALL chromebooks have two finger scrolling HARDWIRED into the trackpad. This means that any contact, no matter how casual, with a second hand, thumb, finger, will cause your screen to scroll either up and down or left to right, or right to left. This happens ALL THE TIME when playing simple games or navigating the internet. Google has NO FIX, and apparently does not care. In fact it has disabled all the previous cures and workarounds for this problem. So unless you like one handed computer operation, or figure out how to retrain your hands so only one finger (and nothing else) ever touches your trackpad, do yourself a BIG favor and buy a cheap microsoft computer and configure it to operate on chrome. It will save you a lot of pain.

Excellent Chromebook for $150. It was on sale at Amazon.

Chromebooks are a quickly rising computer type, that one should consider if they're looking for a basic computer to browse the web on. I really have liked using this to do some more basic homework on over the past few months, it should be said that if you plan on opening lots of more intensive browser windows (like lots of youtube at the same time, and a facebook video), the chromebook will crash. Because it has such low RAM, it's pretty easy to stagger this computer. Sometimes you won't know why, and it'll just reboot. Luckily this is rarely a problem as most things auto save and the computer starts up very quickly, it's only a minor inconvenience.

That being said, this is a cute little laptop that is great if you want something to just throw in your back pack and carry around without stressing about an expensive laptop. Also, with programs like teamviewer and chrome remote desktop, one can easily stream their home computer to their chromebook to do more technical things, I use it to program mostly, but once I even got Portal 2 to run through steam at about 27 fps, although the mouse didn't work through the connection.

I cannot recommend getting this laptop though if you can wait a few months, as of my writing this, Google is working with a few other companies, namely samsung, to integrate android apps better with chromebooks, and in general to greatly improve them on the whole, so if you can wait and don't mind spending another 100 dollars, I would recommend that, or wait and this will be even cheaper.

This laptop is amazing. I bought the older model 1 year ago, which has the exact same specs as this laptop but just has a crummier looking casing. I don't like to usually leave reviews for products unless I stand behind them with my full support, and by god this laptop has done it. I have had laptops from as cheap as $300 all the way to laptops up in the $2500 spot, and nothing has performed as smoothly and RELIABLY as this little baby. The battery lasts around 14 hours when I keep it on low brightness (which is most of the time), the screen quality is clear as long as it's not in direct sunlight, the keyboard and mouse are comfortable, and the speakers are loud enough to hold a small party. Not kidding, I had a few friends over and we didn't even need to go hunting for a speaker to attach. I threw Gallium OS on mine, although Chrome OS should be enough for most users. If you're a developer, the Linux install works great and runs all my C, C++, Python, Java, and C# scripts no problem. Webcam quality is pretty decent, and the microphone had no issues. Hell, I used this thing as a frisbee a few times jokingly with friends and it still works fine, after hitting walls and being dropper a lot. With every laptop I've had I could give you at least 10 complaints by the end of the month, but this laptop has performed above and well beyond expectations. It doesn't work, it just keeps turning on and off.  I can't get it replaced because it's out of stock, so I'll have to contact Acer directly.

The device itself is excellent. The problem is with the charger. I do not know the correct terminology but bear with me. The adapter that plugs into the left side of the machine has a metal pin. If you are charging the machine while watching, as I had done, and you accidentally tap, and I do mean TAP, that pin...it will bend. It is extremely thin and frail and brittle. Now that it's bent, you reinsert it into the machine. But it might not charge. So you have to wiggle it around until you see the little lightning bolt inside the battery indicating that it's charging. But then it stops. If you wiggle it again....and again....ever so gently even, the casing around the pin breaks off into the machine. So now you have a thin pin that you can reinsert and  move around, ever so gently, until that one breaks. I have broken 2 adapters so far. The company is sending me a new one. ADVICE: Put the machine, while charging, in a place where nothing and nobody can get near it. Then very gingerly unplug the charger and put it in some sort of padded safe place until you need to recharge. Maybe on a little featherbed in a cast iron safe. The company seriously needs to redesign that fatal flaw.

It took me a little while to become a Chromebook convert when I first bought my 710 - but once I got the hang over the OS I fell in love. I used it until it burned out and then eagerly looked for a replacement. I wanted nothing to do with other brands - only Acer would do. That, it turned out, was a mistake. I deeply dislike this replacement - a SSD makes no sense in a Chromebook were the memory needs to be dynamic. My computer consistently freezes when I am loading more than 3 webpages at a time. It crashes and requires a restart if more than 10 tabs are open at once. If I am constantly mitigating the number of tabs I have open then this computer is usable. That is as high a praise as I can give it. It can be made to be usable.

Pros: Small and portable, starts in flash
Cons: Chromebook is a fairly useless operating system, computer crashes often, can't handle too many tabs open, which is unfortunate since it chromebook is essentially a browser based OS. Probably going to root this thing. But you get what you pay for I guess, I would just spend the money and get something better.

IT'S ONLY SAYN THERES $30  ON GIFT CARD!!!

I love this little laptop!!  As long as you know what you are buying it is awesome.  As most may know, a Chromebook is not a Windows machine.  And frankly I couldn't have a Chromebook as my main or only computer. With a Chromebook, you can't load and run software on it.  It pretty much is for working on the web, which for me is about 90% of what I do.  The main thing I don't like about working "online only" is when it comes to using Office products.  Many Chromebook users use Google versions of Office applications, however, I've not adopted that approach.  I use Office Online apps like Excel and Word, then save the files to my OneDrive which for the most part is fine...kind of.  I'm not here to review Office 360, but if the online version of Office was a little better I would love my Chromebook even more.

With that said, I find myself using my little Acer Chromebook all the time.  Don't want to sit at my desktop?  Great! I can chill at my couch with this machine.  Even if you do want to use your "main" home machine, Chrome has a web app that allows you to log on to your main machine from your Chromebook.  Your Chromebook then mirrors the other machine just like you are working on that machine.

This Chromebook is so light and portable I often use it in the kitchen to pull up recipes while I'm cooking, I take it on trips for video streaming at hotels.  Also, it works great for Southwest Airlines on-board TV.  You can now download movies from Google Play onto this machine for offline viewing, but there isn't much storage capacity on the SS hard drive (pretty much one movie's worth.)  I have also used this machine's HDMI output for streaming video and connecting to my main home television.  Here, the quality isn't as great as something like Roku, but it is OK if you need to catch up on a few episodes directly from some TV network's website.  BTW, you can also mirror your Chromebook screen to your TV via HDMI which seems to work and look great.

I haven't used the built in camera very much on this, but it appears a bit grainy.  This leads to one of the Chromebook's drawbacks.  I don't believe there is a way to Skype (video) on this which is too bad.  There are other Google web apps I believe you can use instead but I've not tried.

While this Acer Chromebook maybe isn't a isn't a solid 5-stars for me, it is definitely 4.5.  I say this because of the following:

- Outstanding battery life
- It works great (quick start)
- Very reasonable price if you are looking for a second computer
- Light, attractive, and pretty solid feeling build with aluminum external shell
- Versatility: I've had this for about 9 months and continue find new things I can do on it.

Word of warning: If you had a chromebook before this, be sure to Powerwash it before logging into your new chromebook. If you try to log into two chromebooks at a time the thing starts to freak out. This chromebook is a wonderful value for someone who mainly does web-browsing and word-processing, as I do. The display is very clear, and the sound is very crisp. New Acer Chromebook did not function right out of the box.  The Acer Chromebook would just reboot over and over.

Update: after reaching a Google software engineer, going to settings in the guest mode and selecting "about chrome OS" at the top of settings, then selecting "check for and apply updates" a new OS was loaded and the Acer is now working correctly.  The OS on the Acer was so old that it could not get all the updates automatically when the computer startup was executed out of the box.

We purchased this Chromebook back in June and didn't have any problems with it until a month ago when it decided to quit charging and would not power on. Even as a product that sold only for 180$ (the price when I bought), I still don't think it is well worth the money. It lacks the most important, a smooth experience while using.
Problem 1: The tabs froze and crash too frequently, probably because of the minuscule 2GB RAM, it always tell me it has run out of memory, even when I'm just opening 4 tabs. Videos consume a lot of RAM, open 2 youtube videos at the same time, you'll start notice the lag.
Problem 2: It's not just the tabs froze, the Chromebook occasionally froze and my only option is to restart it, or it'll restart by itself anyway after a while.

However, the IPS screen is great. The keyboard is also very comfortable to type. I got a new xps 13 after using this for 2 months. After the keyboard on xps 13 (which is considered to be a premium ultrabook), I still somehow prefer the keyboard on this chromebook. The key travel distance on this chromebook is larger and it's easy to distinguish each keys from another just from touching it. The build quality is also not bad, the plastic feels sturdy enough to withstand bumpy ride in my backpack.

Perhaps if acer manage to bump up the RAM on this to 3gb or 4gb, it would be a much more pleasant experience. I made this purchase with an idea that it would handle my daily task such as browsing and watching videos without problem, which it didn't handle well. (side note: it doesn't handle 1080p well, which is expected anyway)
I'll give it a 3.5/5.

I'm still getting used to my new Chromebook, I've only had it for about a week, but so far, I'm very happy. After my last laptop got hacked, it was going to be too expensive to get it cleaned out, and take too long, so I had to choose something else very quickly. I required a laptop that would be lightweight and easy to carry (long term shoulder injury), that would be pretty inexpensive - yes, we get what we pay for, absolutely, and if I had some disposable income I'd have gone for something around the $300-450 price range, but I don't - and I only need it for writing (love google docs), e-mailing and Internet. I don't use it for games, music or movies - I use my phone and tablet for those things. The Acer Chromebook seemed to fit the bill.
It is lightweight and easy to carry around. It powers up quickly and is easy to navigate. Honestly, it works well for everything I need so far.

The negatives:
1/ Everything is stored on line - literally everything - nothing is downloaded onto the Chromebook and this is something I miss. I thought I would be fine with that, and I most likely will, but I'm still having to get used to it - I liked the convenience of keeping icons on my home screen, but now I can only 'bookmark' webpages instead.

2/ The screen doesn't scroll like my last one did and I thought I wouldn't miss that, but at the moment I do.

These two things I knew about before buying it and aren't something I feel are too bad, just something I'm not yet 100% comfortable with. This is a 'me' thing, not a laptop thing.

But this is a Chromebook 'thing' -
3/ The pad makes quite a 'clunking' noise when I press down to either right or left click. It is actually quite noticeable and quite annoying, so I googled it and it seems that most people find this an issue with this particular model. Some people have posted how to take the back off and fix it themselves, but I'm in no way handy and won't be trying that myself! People nearby me when I'm using it say that they don't notice the clicking sound and that their laptop does it too (not sure about that!). I wish it didn't do this, but I'll learn to live with it, I'm sure.

If I get a couple of years use out of this, I'll be very satisfied, at which time I may well want to upgrade.

I got this for my 70 year old mother after years of struggling with a Windows pc that would constantly get viruses of various kinds on it. All she does is email and browse a few different websites so this was perfect for her. Built in security makes it safe for someone of her age and lack of technological ability. I created a gmail account for her and it's so easy to use. It boots up very fast, and all she has to do is login and it brings her straight to her gmail which is perfect. Easy to browse the Internet and she just loves the touch pad, which is also one large button. You can either tap or push the actual button. She no longer gets confused with the right and left click buttons, and the touch pad is not nearly as sensitive as a windows pc, where we had to disable it because she kept tapping on stuff. Even at her age she wanted a smaller computer, her previous windows of was a 17" and she just LOVED this smaller size. The screen is very nice and easy to see even at her age. Very light and compact as well. I'd recommend this for anyone, but it is especially nice for elderly folks who just like to browse the Internet and do email.

A moderately fast, very small and lightweight netbook. I find Chromium to be a very accessible OS, even though it can't hold a candle to Windows in terms of options. Just a note about this computer: I got the 2GB RAM model, and it has trouble running for long periods of time, particularly because Chrome itself is so RAM-heavy. Often the Chromebook will freeze up and crash, being unresponsive for 5-10 minutes. It's quite annoying, and the offline tools frequently won't work, like Docs or the Drive extension for Chrome (which means you can't copy or paste until you redownload it, every time the computer restarts). When it works, however, it's really great.

Ultimately, I feel like I should have invested in a slightly better Chromebook, but I don't consider this one a waste of money.

Got this for my 11 y/o son. He uses Chrombooks at school and has the school google account. So this was a no brainer. He can access his class work at home without having to worry about either an expensive PC or a cheaper (heavy) PC running windows. The thing is really lightweight and he also uses it for browsing, utube and other games/streaming.
yes the screen is not top of the range, no it has no touch - but its not needed for such a device. For the price, for what it does its perfect (I've had to replace a screen in a tablet and a windows pc because of my kids - if that happens here, I'll just get another one).

Why I purchased: We needed a lap top and quick just for the school year. We don't have a lot of money to be spending, so we decided that something inexpensive like this with good reviews would do the trick.

What I love: I love how lightweight it is. It's an awesome deal for the price of only a little bit over $200. Because we don't use it for gaming or downloading, it works perfectly. It basically needs Internet at all times, so luckily we only use it when we have Internet. It's a great value, honestly, especially if you just need a lap top to do some basic work on and don't want to spend a lot of money.

What I don't love: While I have been pretty happy with this purchase so far, I've already noticed it starting to bug out. We've had to restart it a few times for no apparent reason. When we purchased this, we missed the fact that you need Internet to basically do anything on it, which means that I wasn't always able to work on the go. These are not deal breakers, but these are the reasons for only four stars. It is stellar for the price you pay, however, so I would seriously recommend this to my college friends who don't want to spend too much money on a lap top.

Conclusion: It definitely suits its purpose. It's not the best attribute that it doesn't really work without Internet, but it does its job when you're connected. This means that your computer doesn't slow down with the major taking up of memory, so I kind of like the fact that you save everything onto a "cloud." It's inexpensive, quick, and has had little failures to speak of. Again, I recommend it!

I have intentionally not looked at the other customer reviews so they wouldn't influence me. I'm brand new to Chromebooks, and after 3 months this is my impression.

What I like:
- Others can log in on my computer using their Gmail addresses and it becomes "their" computer and they can't see my files, web history, etc. So you can freely lend your computer to friends, family, etc., to check email or whatever.
- The computer is small and light.
- You don't have to worry about the computer getting stolen, since your stuff is on the cloud.
- Great for web browsing and email.
- Allows the Dvorak keyboard!

What I do not like/what needs to be improved:
- The file system is mega confusing. I wish they could have it set up in simple folders or directories like Windows and Mac have.
- The Google Sheets aspect is somewhat broken compared with using Google Sheets on a Mac. For example, it's impossible to open a csv file with a table, reorder the data, and copy 'n paste it all into a Google Sheet on the Chromebook, but it does work on Windows or Mac.
- The extensions are confusing. I wish there could be a simple list of what extensions you have and what you can use or deactivate. (Maybe there is such a list, but I can't find it.)
- Supposedly you have access now to Android apps, but it's non-intuitive.
- No way to adjust screen colors for night mode (removal of blue light), like you can on iPhone, Mac, and Kindle Fire.
- If you close the lid to put the computer to sleep, sometimes the screen won't turn back on. You have to just turn the thing off and on, rather than putting it to sleep, which makes the process slower.
A nice laptop no problems so far, sometimes pages load a little slow but probably my Internet because my phone does the same thing.

I was looking for a compact, inexpensive laptop I could take with me to professional education seminars for my job, as well as carry around the house. After doing some extensive research, I settled on this Chromebook. After using it for a few months, I can recommend this to anyone looking for a ~$150 laptop and/or considering jumping into the Chromebook arena for the first time.

PROS:
- Super quick startup. Turning on the Chromebook, I can be logged in under a minute.
- Great battery life. This laptop can last me an entire day at a seminar unplugged (8+ hours of continuous use). My previous laptops would need to be charged after half a day at most.
- Small and compact. I bought a handheld carrying case to go along with my Chromebook and now it's so much easier to bring my laptop with me places. The days of lugging a laptop in an over-the-shoulder are over!
- Quick and unintrusive updates.
- Compatible with my Logitech mouse. I plugged in the USB receiver and I was able to use my wireless mouse immediately.
- Inexpensive. If this were to break or get lost, it wouldn't be a huge loss. This is also a negative aspect, as you'll see below.

CONS:
- Inexpensive. Don't expect lightning fast Internet browsing with this Chromebook. Streaming videos can take upwards of 30 seconds to one minute to load. I expected this though when I reviewed the specs and price. For the price, this is fine.
- Not MS Office compatible. The online version is available, of course, but if you need Word, Excel, etc. look elsewhere. Google's office suite is available though, and this would probably suffice for most people's needs.
- Wifi Internet only. At home, it would nice to have the option for a wired Internet connection, but this is not an option as far as I'm aware with this Chromebook.
- Trackpad gestures aren't very intuitive. I had to Google how to right-click with the trackpad. Hitting the right bottom corner of the trackpad with a single finger does not trigger a right-click as I would have expected. You need to use two fingers. That's why I usually use my wireless mouse with this Chromebook.

Overall, I really like this laptop given its price range. Don't buy this laptop expecting it to be a powerhouse. It's perfect for casual Internet browsing and very light office productivity work. If you're looking for an inexpensive laptop or if you're considering buying your first Chromebook but don't want to drop a lot of money on it, this is a great offering. Manage your expectations before purchasing!

If you are new to Chromebooks like me, note that you cannot sync Apple products at all and I found that even trying to charge through the USB is impossible.  You also save all files into the Google drive, nothing is local, so if you are wanting to move files from another device to clean it off you basically have to save it up to the Google drive from that device, and then you can view them on this machine.  There are positives to having a Google-dedicated machine because it sort of organizes itself and all your files (like Hal would I guess...) but if you also have Apple products, it is worth considering the annoyance of not being able to charge your phone off of it if you are out and about.  All that said though, I would buy it again.

Background:
I am a college student who has a computer that is so heavy and cumbersome not to mention the battery life is regularly around 3 hours which is not enough to take it to campus for the day.  I wanted a computer to take on campus so I could do some online homework and surf the web if time allowed, and after that, still had enough battery life so i would be fine if i forgot to charge it at night.  I researched into different chromebooks and i have a friend who has the previous generation of this computer, the Acer Chromebook CB-111.

Price:
Probably the main reason that i purchased this chromebook, especially at the price for what you are getting, this is a very nice laptop.

Feel:
This laptop is made out of plastic, but not the plastic that you touch and you think you are going to break.  It is a nice matte texture and feels solid to hold.  The feel of the keys is more textured, and coupled with the not-completely-mushy keys, makes this laptop fun to type on.  The trackpad is one of the parts of this laptop where it shows its price; the trackpad is plastic as well, and it is definitely not as nice as glass when it comes to sliding your finger across it.  Your finger is more prone to friction when moving across the trackpad than with a glass trackpad.  This is not something that will bug you until the day that you get rid of the computer, it takes about a day to get used to it, and then you never notice it again.

Screen:
You are going to like looking at the screen. since the screen size is smaller, you don't even notice that it isn't full HD.

Performance:
The whole thing about chrome OS is that google built it to be fast, responsive and lightweight. You are not going to be running full Photoshop on this, sure, but that isn't the purpose for this computer. The Chromebook is for someone who is using it for some surfing the web, editing text docs. Perfect for the average college student. That being said, the 2GB of RAM that are in this computer is enough to get you through your day of editing docs, surfing the web and emails.  If you try to have 20 tabs open, all running CPU intensive tasks, yes, the computer is going to stutter.  It would be like four instances of Photoshop on an PC all stitching together panoramas. With the 2GB of RAM, I have been pleasantly surprised with what it can do. I regularly have my email open in one tab, google hangouts in another tab, google keep open, editing a google doc and listening to google play music on the counter and I haven't noticed the computer stuttering with all of those programs running.  If you want to run programs that your PC can run, you can always just remotely access your computer using Chrome Remote Desktop, and then you can access the power of your PC directly from your Chromebook.  Be warned; however, that running Chrome Remote Desktop uses up the battery much faster than just surfing the web.

All in all:
Like I have said before, this is perfect for a college student who wants to take notes in class, do their online homework while still on campus, edit their essay and after all that, have their computer be at 50% battery.  A fantastic Chromebook that has just the right amount of everything.

You have to log-in with your Google sign in but you can add enough privacy plug-ins like ghostery, AdBlockPlus, & EFF's badger to make it feel more locked down/clean. It also has the option to do a full purge of your personal data if you decide to get rid of it.

First I will say this Chromebook handled everything I threw at it. Netflix, Amazon Prime Video, Pandora, Plex Movie stream, Xfininity Video Stream and so much more. Flash and java heavy websites just all seemed to work! I even ran some 4k youtube videos and after buffering they played, but really you do not need 4k when you don't have a 4k screen. The screen on this chrombeook is IPS and looks clean clear and is responsive; much nicer than other chromebooks I've seen. I have had multiple streams video and music open while browsing multiple tabs, but really I would never do this unless testing and it all ran perfectly. This was reported to be the best chromebook on the mark for 2016 for the price and it has not let me down.

Sometimes I find myself with 20 plus tabs open and do see the machine slowing down when scrolling websites, but this is my issue as I am a tab junky. Less than 10 tabs and I have no issues. Also, I will say because of the RAM I have to be more selective on my Chrome Extensions, but I have this issue on my beefy computer with 16 GB of RAM sometimes and this is not a fault of the Chromebook.

Hope this review helps someone interested in a great Chromebook. I do not usually write reviews, just read them.

Make sure you research how a Chromebook works before you buy it so you know whether or not it fits your personal needs. For example, Chromebooks only work with Google Cloud Print compatible printers so make sure you own one before buying. Also, Chromebooks are very limited offline, so know your limits. It was a perfect fit for me, because as a college student studying Early Childhood Education, all I needed was a laptop that could surf the internet and access Word online. If you aren't a fan of Google (Chrome, Drive, Photos, Gmail) do not buy this laptop.

I bought this for grad school, in lieu of using a very large and too-heavy laptop - I needed something more easily portable for running back and forth to libraries and campus.  This is my first Chromebook and I have to say I'm QUITE impressed.  I remember when they first came out people were complaining about how limiting they are, that they only work when connected to wifi, only work with certain applications, you can't do this, can't do that, etc, etc.  I have found ZERO limitations, at least in terms of anything I've tried to do with it.  The speed with which it comes up and is ready to go is astonishing - I'm so accustomed to processors and programs having to all boot up while I drink a cup of coffee waiting on it, this thing is practically always "on" or at least as close to "on" as a computer can get.  It's small and light profile makes it so easy to throw in a bag and go, I've even been able to cut back to a smaller book bag because this just takes up less space.

I have to say the battery life is also one of the most remarkable aspects of this device.  I always see to it that it's fully charged before I head off to a day at the library, but even after spending LITERALLY all day at a library, working non stop on the computer and even doing data-heavy operations that should hit the battery pretty hard, I can still count on leaving the library at the end of the day with a good 3-6 HOURS of battery life still showing.  I've taken to not even bothering to pack my charger anymore - it's unnecessary.  No more worrying about finding a spot in the library or coffee shop that is close to a charger, which is remarkably freeing.

I'm SOLD on Chromebooks, I think if my big huge laptop ever dies I'll just replace it with one of these.  For years I thought I HAD to have a windows laptop because of my need for word processing, excel, etc, but when I bought this I started using Google docs and have fallen in love with that completely.  I love that no matter where or on what device I sign into my Google account my documents are there, waiting on me.
