For the most part, this product exceeds my expectations. The build quality feels very solid. Although its entire body is plastic (aside for the aluminum plate on the lid), there is absolutely no noticeable flex on the keyboard, and hardly any on the lid. Also, the hinge feels very solid when opening and closing it.
The keyboard feels good to type on and the track pad is quite decent. I'm quite happy to get an IPS panel on such an inexpensive computer. It looks quite good when looking straight on, but looses some brightness when looking at extreme angles (but this doesn't bother me).
One thing which was very surprising to me (aside from the solid build quality) were the speakers. They are plenty loud enough for almost any listening conditions, (and a lot better than those of other laptops I've used).
The wifi works very well and the battery life seems quite good (probably around 6 hrs with constant heavy use). The webcam and the microphone are quite good.
The only thing I can really complain about is the small amount of RAM. Having more than 5 chrome tabs open usually results in significant slow downs. However, the ability to use Chrome Remote Desktop or Team Viewer to connect to my desktop can be used to negate this RAM issue and also use Windows exclusive programs.
Overall, I see this laptop as being very well made and having very competent components. If you plan on doing many things at once, I highly recommend opting for something with more RAM. If you plan on using this for remote controlling another computer, I see this as a good, inexpensive option.

Oh man. This is the little laptop that can. I've wanted a Chromebook for a while just as a tinker laptop. As a developer, I'm always looking for new tech to experiment with and this hasn't let me down. I find myself reaching for it more than any other device now. (Including an iPad Pro which used to be my go-to for getting on the web at home.)

The size is perfect. It's not going to replace my home computer nor my development laptop. But it's the right size and weight to grab whenever I nee a computer "right now" to look up something, compose a quick email, etc. I even use it for presenting during our daily meetings connected to a projector. Chrome itself is superb if you're doing nothing more than using the internet. I've even found enough solutions for more fringe stuff that I want to be able to do. For example, I have a vast assortment of plain text notes stored in Dropbox that need to be accessed anywhere. I've found a fantastic Chrome OS editor (Caret) and installed the Dropbox filesystem support for Chrome OS, and now I have access to all those notes.

I admit to having also opened up developer mode so I could install Ubuntu to create a web server for development as a proof of concept. I won't get much into that there, but it's something I've done.

I will also admit that this isn't a fast computer. Web pages (even Google's own) are slowish to load. For most people, this will be a non-issue. For someone used to gigabit ethernet on an i7 based computer, yeah, you're going to notice it. And yet I still continue to reach for it.

The keyboard is great, and the trackpad works surprisingly well. Google must have spent some time finessing the drivers because it works better in Chrome OS than it does in Ubuntu. The keyboard is good sized and the keys are adequately responsive with acceptable travel. I really enjoy typing on it.

The display is ... well, great for this price point. But even though it's an IPS, it's not exactly Apple quality. But, again, at this price point, I'm thrilled with how good it IS. It's unlikely one is likely to complain about display quality at this price point. I do not believe you can find another IPS Chromebook in this price range.

Battery life is phenomenal. I haven't measured it, but I have used it heavily and just been amazed that it keeps on going. I can use it all weekend and take it back to work to charge on Monday.

Rather than just ramble, I'll say that this is a great deal and a fine little computer. It's not the fastest or the most feature rich, but for the price it gets the job done quite well. Enough that this power user often finds myself going to it to handle all the small tasks throughout the day. If you're on a shoestring budget (or you like to tinker) grab one and be glad you did. If you need a computer that can run everything in the sun, then you're still going to want a Windows or Mac - that's just life. But if you (like so many) do 95% of your computing on the internet, this might be the device for you.

Light, Thin, Sturdy Feels /looks Like a Macbook Air. Silent fanless operation. 5 second boot up time, faster than a tablet to boot up. Battery life is the best I've experienced. 8am to 5pm continuous running with wifi on is possible, so long as you keep screen brightness to pre-set 75% level. Chrome has limitations so be aware of those if you're used to a windows experience. Skype cannot be used out of the box for example. You need to download and configure a browser extension "ARChon" to run the Android tablet version of Skype. It works ok. Bit laggy, and at times delayed video to audio sync. Official Google android runtime version should be better supported and is due for roll out / release soon. Most chromebook users will automatically be updated to allow google Play store apps / extensions to be used on chromebooks. Mostly this notebook feels snappy, loads content rich web pages fast enough and is ideal for general office/student/home user tasks like word processing, listening to music (the speakers are surprisingly loud and clear, much better than I expected) watching Youtube, Social media (if you're into that kind of thing) etc... Well worth the price.

Coming off a Windows based laptop, I really loved my new Chromebook until it unexpectedly "died" on me after only 6 weeks of use- no display, no lights, no warning. Since it was past Amazon's 30 day warranty,  I had to deal with Acer's Warranty support.

It broke on a Saturday, I immediately called the Warranty repair number (866-695-2237) and supprisingly someone quickly answered and helped me try to revive it to no avail. So they emailed me a pre-paid shipping label (good thing I saved the box) to send it to Texas for repair. They promised me a 5-7 business day turn around time. They made good on this promise, as I received it back in 5 days after they received it, good as new. According to the repair tag, they replaced the main board, LCD display & battery.

ONE YEAR AFTER PURCHASE UPDATE:
Basically no help from ACER support off warranty, Had to repair myself:

Started experiencing the following symptoms:

1. Shutdown pushbutton does not work

2. Chrome browser crashed  at least once a week. Screen pixelates, then dissolves, but cursor still works and activates whatever is underneath it.

3. Now  the screen was totally dead (unit was fully charged, power adaptor putting out correct voltage)
 Had to open up the back, unplugged / then plugged in battery cable,  finally came back to life. THIS FIX SEEMED TO HAVE SOLVED ALL MY ABOVE ISSUES.
To date, this unit has now worked good as new.  Keeping my fingers crossed....

I picked one of these up at Target, where they're currently less expensive than they are here.

I usually hate buying retail, but the lower price, plus the fact that I wanted to act immediately, led me to take the plunge. I had decided about 48 hours earlier that I needed a dedicated, stripped-down machine for my writing (professional need) that would spare me the distractions and unnecessary pauses that occur across every part of "regular" computer use.

As it turns out, this was my *second* Chromebook in 48 hours. My first was a Lenovo Ideapad 100s, which is now on it's way back to the manufacturer as defective. It arrived out of the box with a spontaneous reboot problem that I couldn't resolve, and thatplus what I'm about to sayput me off the Lenovo unit, despite the fact that it's on sale in some retail stores for as low as $129 right now.

In comparison to the Lenovo unit (which has the same electronic specifications), this Acer unit is:

- Smaller in every dimension
- Lighter
- More attractive
- Blessed with a far better screen (same resolution and technology, but the difference is clear)
- Longer-lasting on battery power
- Just as sturdy in construction (i.e. not super sturdy, but not frighteningly flimsy either)

So while the Acer was just a tad more expensive, I'm much happier with this unit than I would have been with the Lenovo, even if it had worked properly straight out of the boxwhich it didn't.

This is my first Chromebook i purchased it for College and I LOVE it!

My university runs a lot via gmail so the fact that i connects to everything and all my important papers, research and data is in one place.
So far i have also had no problems with accessing online educational sites for homework/quizzes/videos etc.

The Chromebook starts right up and is super quiet, i have not had any issues with it freezing on me, matter of fact I am very satisfied with how quick it is. It is light weight and fits in any backpack or even larger purse and it think its overall size is perfect.

Bought this laptop as something I could take to class for notes, etc.  My previous HP laptop is fantastic but the battery lasts two hours on the dimmest screen setting.  I didn't want to drop $1200 on a CAD-capable laptop, so I have this Chromebook and a separate desktop at home that's capable.

The idea was, this Chromebook is capable of everything I need to do while at school and when I get home, I can do the real number-crunching.  I just got it yesterday, and I used it for six hours typing my lab report.  I've used it an hour today and the battery is at 43%; that's ridiculous!  I didn't even have the screen dim, it's about in the middle.  I watched some YouTube for an hour or so, played music, etc.  Works great.

Keyboard feels great, yes the touchpad click requires a BIG push to click it, but tapping on it also works to click (tapping like you would on a smartphone).  Chrome OS updated itself when I got it which took a bit of a hit on my internet speed, but no matter, it's decent.  When I plugged it in to my 1080p monitor, keyboard and mouse ("docking" it) it worked fine, but it isn't as smooth, if you will, as my windows PC.  But for $150, this is a fantastic deal and it will definitely get the job done, well.  If you haven't already, go for it!

-- EDIT after 2 years of use --
Battery life has not degraded noticeably and I still can't remember the last time I charged it, haha!  Definitely nearly a week of using it in class for notes in a charge.  Also, the charger is pretty quick; 45 minutes on the charger went from 25% to 75%.

I did have a small issue with the chassis.  I didn't drop the laptop, but I do put it in the 'laptop' compartment of my backpack which places it right against your back.  I then rode my bike to school and the chassis seemed twisted (on the table, it would rock like a wobbly chair).  To fix this, I just used my hands and bent it back and it fixed it.  That tells me the chassis isn't metal but plastic -- just something to keep in mind.

I further reiterate that this laptop is certainly no rocketship.  It gets the job done, but google drive (ironically) is one of the laggiest websites along with facebook.  It's a shame, because google drive is where I take notes for class, so I often need to rush into class, open it, navigate into the correct class folder, create a new document, and title it as fast as possible and typically it isn't ... that fast.  Anyhow, FWIW this laptop is fine for what it's designed to do.
this newer version is great and the sound is much louder.

I never took Chromebooks seriously, but decided to open my mind and try.

Wow, what a fantastic device.

I work in IT (20+ years) and have some relatively powerful machines (Retina MacBook Pro and ThinkPads) that I use daily for work, but this Chromebook is my go-to device when I'm not running virtual machines or coding.  The rounded edges (no wrist-cutting sharp edges like on too many trendy devices these days), good keyboard, glare-free screen, instant-on, battery life, and most of all, the simplicity make it a real joy to use.

I was surprised that the mouse pointer disappears when not needed, just like on the Mac.  Mac-like Expose was also nice to discover.  It's more refined than Google would lead you to believe looking at their Chromebook website.  Well done, Google--you should let people know about these little bits of awesomeness.

I was also super impressed that my Meridian Explorer DAC just works--paired with Sony Pro headphones this thing rocks.  Even without headphones it impresses; the speakers are astonishingly loud and not tinny.  SD cards sit flush with the left edge, which means I can load up a card with music and files and just leave it in the machine and forget it's there.  It would be nice if screen resolution was Full HD, but I zoom most things anyway, so that's not that big of a deal.

All-around it's a great device.  I bought one for everyone in the family, even though we all already have Apple devices of all shapes and sizes--and everyone loves the Chromebook.  I struggle to find a more long-term enjoyable use of $180.

I've had this chromebook for over a month and am very happy with it. It's compact, lightweight, impressively fast, and, most importantly, reliable. I bought this for work because my job requires me to drive to multiple clients homes each day and do some light data entry on the computer while I'm there. It works great for that purpose but I also find myself choosing to use the chromebook instead of my MacBook Pro while at home and browsing the web or watching Netflix, even though the screen is a bit smaller it really doesn't bother me. It's just that much faster than my MacBook.
I love this little gem. Very light weight and thin, fitting into my bag easily for travel. Only drawback is not being able to do things that require Window's. Nice keyboard and clear picture.
This Chromebook picked up right where my previous model stopped when it crashed!  I did not need to set up apps or passwords!

I needed a backup laptop of sorts. First I was turned off because it was called the non laptop. But when I had issues with another product I had tried I took my fiancee's advice and purchased this chromebook. It is light weight so speedy and easy to set up. I have my hand sd card for all my media and pictures. I also love that it plays my video files without needing a certain player. Also a great great feature is that now you can edit and write in google docs off line. I have only had it a few days and I am in love with it. It will be my go to when I travel or don't want to boot up my main computer.

I think this product would be great for students,teens anyone who spends alot of time in the chrome browser. Another plus is Tumblr doesn't lag on it as much as it has on other products. I give it a five star review.
Great as a video device casting to a chromecast.
Incredible value.
Google spreadsheets does not work on this laptop....one of the main reasons I bought this to begin with. I have not touched the laptop since I got it in the mail....over a month ago! Ugh!
Perfect size and easy to use.

We have seen disruptive technologies before like the smartphone, and I'm now typing on one of those new disruptive technologies.  It's a Chromebook, and I'm in awe of its' simplicity and power.

No, it is not a powerhouse, at 2G Ram and 16G SSD, it isn't going to replace any number crunching MacBook Pro or Dell laptop.  What it is though, is the embodiment of online services for most of our day to day work.

Day to day work is email, calendars, notes, spreadsheets, presentations.  Unless you are a working with large and complex files, this little thing can do it.  This little thing, that costs $180, can do most of what you do.
Initial impression is highly favorable!  For the price it's incredible!  Keyboard and screen were very nice.  Easy to use and setup.  Great for surfing the web and email.  Highly secure for banking.
my son loves this chromebook!  super fast.  he loves it.
hell yeah! get it!
It has been great.  It is easy.  Boots up quickly.  Don't have to worry about the chores of security scans since they are done automatically.  It is just a fun easy way to play on line easily.
for the price point cant complain. Very light and very portable. Use it for primarily for web surfing, email, and google docs for school assignments. Im very pleased with this purchase.

This Chromebook just replaced my laptop no viruses ever you can play games surf and view ebooks and with the added benefit of an SD card slot you can store music movies ebooks. Had my chromebook for a few days and I love it! It boots so fast and it's so easy to whiz around the internet. I got it as a secondary computer, so I can leave my main computer at my office. Great product, great price, love my lil chromebooks, this is the 3d one I have purchased some were other company names, but on the whole they are great lil machines, fast and keep you protected at all times from viruses.

ERR MERRR GEEERRRRHHHDDDD!!!!! I LOVE THIS DAMN LAPTOP!!!!!! This is hands down #1 in my book of laptops. All I had to do was get an external drive for my files because the memory won't go far BUT the Chromebook was so affordable that I could buy 6 external hard drives if I wanted to. MUAHAHAHAH!!!! I love it! Now I can work from home by day and be a maniacal Super Villain by night. LoL just kidding. I don't work from home! :D
Good!
Nice little laptop for the price. Fast startup. I use it mostly for watching online training videos, browsing the internet, checking my email. Does everything I need it to do. No problems so far.

I had an Acer Netbook that I purchased a few years ago, and while it was okay, it didn't last. It quickly became very laggy, so you can see where my concerns were when I finally decided to purchase an Acer Chromebook. I'm so glad I did. I've had it for about a month and this little machine is perfect!!!

Pro's:
-Beautiful screen, with a good range of brightness options
-Functional keyboard, with good spacing between keys
-Love the sound, even though it seems the two speakers are very small. It provides a 'full' sound.
-The charge lasts for roughly 9-10 hours with typical use (Facebook, online shopping, etc), and about 5-6 hours with Netflix
-Very quick when jumping from page to page or loading things
-Very light overall

Cons:
-Only comes with two usb ports (which stinks if I want to use a usb mouse, then I'm down to one)
-Google Play store doesn't have enough 'favorite games' that I play with my Android phone
-Loud touchpad mouse. This seems like an odd thing to say, but when I 'click' the mouse, it makes a very loud sound and quickly becomes obnoxious
-The top of the lid is rough, which makes decals hard to stick (and stay on)

This Chromebook is perfect for the work I need to do, and also it great for the online shopping, buying music, or just playing around. I absolutely love this thing!!!!!!!!!
Super dumper, I love this little machine. I did right decision with not going for super brand expensive chromebook. I really like to work and play with it. Plus white color is just so chic.
Great product.
Fast. Easy to use. Smooth, responsive keyboard and touch pad. Light but durable and looks nice.
small and portable, very nice, still figuring it out
I'm sorry I wanted to like Chromebooks but I just can t its to small for my big hands I have a Toshiba laptop that is way bigger than a chromebook. Chromebooks,I just can't handle it

Firstly, I will say this: this is a lovely computer.

This laptop could easily be bent, and as a result, that very thing happened when I put my computer into my backpack. It works at the very least. But it wasn't the most pretty computer after the bend.

Lesson to take away from this: when planning to carry the computer around, be gentle.

This small compact chromebook is just the right size.... Ten minutes after I got it I flashed the BIOS and put GalliumOS on it (Linux for Chromebooks). Works like a charm. I am using an SD card as my "main hard disk" but with Gallium there is still about 11GB free in the built-in SSD. Light, great battery life, decent display size are all pluses. The only minus is the keyboard. It's not "bad" -- just no home key positions making touch typing a bit difficult at first.

Love that it is fast, has a keyboard, easy to get on and don't have to worry about viruses.  Hard to find a printer that works on it. Cannot download apps such as turbotax, some say you can use the cloud tax program but it won't help if you cant print it.  Can get apps on the google web store sich as the kindle app to read books. I bought this computer for my 10yr old daughter. It is her first computer. I told her I would use it for a couple days to see if it is something that I can also buy for her 9yr old sister. I have an older Acer that I love, but this little thing is amazing! I want to keep this for myself! The packaging was great and upon opening it, the battery was dead but I was able to plug in the computer and use it immediately. It went through a typical set up but was super easy and quick to set up! I have had it now for two days and last night I used to play music to sleep to for NINE hours on just the battery and when I woke up, it was still going! It is zippy and the feel of it is super light and feels sturdy. it feels like it has some sort of powder coating on the shell. The only weird thing I am finding about it is the keyboard is a little different than the one on my bigger Acer, but that is to be expected and can easily get used to it. What is already loaded on the computer with icons at the bottom is the Google Chrome search engine, Gmail, Google docs and youtube. So, even if you need a word processor, Google docs can do about anything and you can just download what you need from there. If you are a parent on the fence about getting your kid a computer that is simple with not alot of bloatware, this is seriously the one for you! I wish I would have just bought this for them instead of a Kindle last Christmas! This has so many more features! There are two USB ports, one on each side, a headphone jack so if you are going for a long trip, not only will the battery last a long time for you, but each kid can have their own thing going on. There is also an HDMI port as well as SD. Oh! and the speakers are GREAT! You would think out of a little thing like this, that the speakers would not be very good. They are located on the bottom but are very loud when turned up. Enjoy! Cannot beat what this little machine has to offer for the price!
When I first got it I couldn't get it but now I really like and enjoy it.
I love this Chromebook more than I imagine loving my future firstborn child. It's the best thing since gluten free waffles. Seriously.
I love my chrome book I have nothing negative to say about it.  Best purchase I've made

This Chromebook is lightweight and holds a charge all day. I'm a public-school teacher on a budget, and since my district uses the Google suite for education, this fit the bill perfectly. I've used it daily for almost a year, and it serves all my needs, from streaming online videos, to creating documents through Google, to grading, even, using multiple online programs. If you can subsist on using the browser alone for all your tech needs, this night be the only little computer you need. When my kids get old enough to require their own laptops, I would not mind investing in these, because they are so cost effective and handy.

This is my first chromebook and also my first laptop. I own a decade old Dell computer and while it suits me for the most part I was looking for a cheap alternative to a portable computer, and this fits the bill perfectly! So small and light enough for me to carry around practically anywhere without taking up much space. It has a nice, bright screen and a long battery life. I was a bit concerned at first because people were saying 2 GB of ram is not very useful because it is too slow, but so far I haven't noticed any problems as far as speed is concerned. I have been playing a game called Arcane Legends and have had no lag at all.

The keyboard took a little getting use to, as did the OS. Chromebooks are not for everyone as they can't do everything a regular laptop can. I don't really like the fact that it's mostly an online device, but you can run and edit documents offline and if necessary you can download documents and save them to the chromebook itself or to an SD card. I did find the USB ports to be a bit funky though--it took a minute or two to get the devices to fit in and the same for taking them out. After a few tries, however, they go in and out well enough. The only other gripe I can think of at the moment is clicking on the bottom of the mousepad involves pressing down rather firmly and the noise is a bit loud for my taste. I usually just use the touch gesture for quiet clicking.

All in all this is a very handy little laptop and I can see why it would be considered useful for schoolwork and things. My sister received a new laptop as a gift and it's amusing how often she has to charge her laptop while I can use mine practically all day without plugging it in. So yes, I am very satisfied with this purchase and will update this review in the future to see how well it holds up.
Touchpad is not good quality but overall works great.

Very happy with it

The price is amazing and I am recommending it to everyone that is looking into getting an inexpensive laptop!  Kudos Acer!

speeds are about the same though the screen on the acer is also very very nice its not as good as the toshiba chromebook 2 but pretty damn close

The screen is so clear, but also does good and doesn't glare in sun. Its light weight, not the sleekest design, but does the job. The track pad is a little different to get to used to, but then super convenient. You push down a little harder for it to actually 'click' in order to drag or highlight text, but a simple tap (no click noise) does the job for a regular click. using to fingers to tap instead of one is a 'right click' and two fingers left, right, up or down can scroll. three fingers right and left switches between tabs. I use it for work, a web based CRM program, and then we heavily use good sheets, gmail, and dropbox, and it really does the job without being bogged down by all the software and regular computer stuff. I find myself sometimes trying to open something like calculator, but just have to google search a calendar and use something web-based. chromebook is bomb. happy with my purchase.

I bought the first Acer Chromebook when it was released and loved it. I'm not enjoying this one as much. Aesthetically, it's ugly and clunky compared to its predecessor, which was much more sleek and slender. It's not as fast as my last one was when I first bought it. I don't know if I have a faulty battery, but I'm also not getting close to the amount of work time out of it as I did with the older model when it was new. And the four pads on the underside of the laptop that are meant to grip the surface below are quite plasticy, allowing it to slide around a lot. A minor issue, I know, but incredibly annoying.

I've owned multiple Acer products and have been pleased with all of them, so I'm surprised to be so disappointed by this Chromebook. While I would absolutely recommend a Chromebook in general, I would suggest trying another manufacturer for this run. My laptop started slowing down and I needed something where I could do my practice exams on but didn't want to spend money on a new laptop. This works perfectly. If you only need Internet and maybe have to write down a few notes here and then ( you can do that on google drive) then this is perfect. The battery life is amazing. I take it to the library in the morning and come back in the evening and don't have to charge it even once.

My old laptop died, and I generally use laptops only for web browsing, chat, editing/writing, and streaming music and videos.  For this purpose, this chromebook is everything I'd hoped it would be.  It is very lightweight and portable, with a sturdy build for the price.  No start-up or shut-down time, which I also love; it is similar to using an iPad or tablet in this sense.  I required a full keyboard for writing and editing documents, and the keyboard feels comfortable. The keys are slightly smaller than on standard keyboards, but it is so slight that I've had no trouble adapting as a typist.

This is my first time using Chrome OS, coming from a long time using Windows OS.  What I enjoyed the most was the first start-up.  The instructions are as simple as: Plug-in, turn on.  Logging in was simple (with my gmail account), and all bookmarks were transferred because I've been using Chrome browser for years.  There was no ad-ware I needed to uninstall.  The navigation is simple and easy to use - and I will comment the wallpaper selection it comes with is full of very beautiful photographs from around the world.

The battery life is as advertised; a full charge lasts me 7 - 9 hours depending on if I brighten or darken the screen.  The charger charges quickly, taking about 1-2 hours to recharge from empty.
The screen is a little too small but I can live with it.

This computer is unbeatable for $165. But, be aware that it's a Chromebook, and 'cloud based" Chromebooks are different from traditional "storage on-board" computers. I have used a Chromebook for four years and the concept of "cloud based" suits me fine. If you are not sure what "cloud based" means, get a friend to explain. For $165, this is an unbelieveable value.

all i needed

I'm beyond happy with this purchase. Let me start by saying I bought this more to play around with ChromeOS and to see how viable Chromebooks were not expecting to like it as much as I did.

With that being said, if you do the majority of your work on web based apps then you're going to have no problem using this every day.

My main problem with it is that apps like Dropbox just redirect you to the webpage and don't actually offer a good app experience like on a tablet. I think that this is something that could be fixed through updates, but it's a problem I saw on several apps.

Definitely worth the money.

I wanted to replace our Mac which was eight years old. I did photo editing and music track composition as well as true usual office type tasks. I would have laughed a few years ago at the idea of a chromebook which is a fraction of the cost of a good computer. Yet, if you are tech savy, there are workarounds and apps that you can use that can make his work - so not to the extent of a thousand dollar computer - but this is more like comparing a Jeep to a Lexus, it could get you where you want to go - maybe not as fast, and it can take you to some new really cool places. Switching to a Google environment is not a big sacrifice. As for internal memory, remember you have a 3.0 USB, a 2.0 USB, a SD card slot and a regular size HDMI port. Plus, since most Apps are actually secure shortcuts to Google or other websites, much of what you do will be stored in the cloud anyway. There are sites that allow you to do music track mutitracking, photo editing, even computer coding.

No, you can't have 20 tabs open or throw heavy tasks at this and expect it to perform like a costly machine. You also can't do heavy graphic intensive gaming, but you would struggle with these tasks anyway on computers costing twice the amount of this thing.

Pair it with a keyboard that has a finger touchpad (instead of a mouse) and look for apps that do what you are used to doing on a regular computer. Also add a good USB thumbdrive, external drive, or SD card and you will be wondering why most people aren't buying a chromebook like this one.

Many people don't get these because they assume that they need so much more, like I did. Yet, it works for me with very few real sacrifices and some gains.

Also, I want to add that the screen size is big enough, and you can always (ALT) + (+) to zoom in or HDMI it to a Large HD TV or monitor.
It's easy to use
Okay I'll admit that this computer is really good for studying. An. Playing online games.  But if u wanna download games such as Minecraft,  the Sims and more this computer doesn't allow that

I am blown away by this little Chromebook. I am a Mac man and I am amazed at this little machine. It makes me sick how much I spent on my Macbook Air especially seeing the screens side by side. I am a professional photographer and I like to make sure my screens look good on my devices. Is the resolution as good as a 1080p screen, no, but my goodness for $160 this does the job amazingly well! With the IPS display it absolutely puts my Macbook air to shame. Colors are more vivid, viewing angles better, and it appears crisper even though the resolutions are the same. Yes, I know my Macbook air can do more but when you need to check email, upload some photos with quick edits, and browse the days news why spend $800? Plus, if I drop this bad boy or something happens to it I won't cry over $169. Need something to do the basics and then some while not sacrificing the display? This is your Chromebook!

Sidenote: I owned the first version of the toshiba chromebook 2 and the screen was amazing however the build quality was not. Watching the screen lid bend every time I opened it was cringe inducing. This acer feels much better built. I hear the newest toshiba chromebook 2 is much better built.

I have an Acer Chromebook CB3-111.k It is much better than the CB3-131. This one is much slower, locks up, and crashes continuously. I mean once every half hour. It is junk! The 111 is much superior!

I just got my Acer Chromebook last week, and even though now I'm pretty satisfied with it, it's not getting a 5-star because I had to do some work to get to where I am now. The machine looked pretty solid, everything was working fine, except, this Chromebook didn't recognize my phone to do file transfers at first. I searched the web and tried a few things, but finally I contacted Chrome Support (NOT Acer support). They were really helpful. I got help via online chat. Turned out, my Chrome OS wasn't the latest version even though on Chrome page, it said my Chrome OS was up to date. Powerwash didn't do the work, so we finally did an OS reinstall using a 4GB SD card (that I happened to have!). After that, it recognized my phone, and now everything is working perfectly! For the money I paid for this Chromebook, I am willing to conclude that this extra step was acceptable. Now I hope this Chromebook will last for at least a few years.... Considering that phones usually have a short life, I'm not surprised Chromebooks are kind of the same way.

In a nutshell: For the right person this could be a game changer. If you are aware of the limitations (and strengths) of Chrome OS and are thinking about taking the leap to a Chromebook, this well-built and surprisingly speedy laptop has a charm that could appeal to you.

I consider myself a pc power user: I have a dedicated custom-built desktop for my hardcore gaming and heavy software suites, as well as a fairly beefy laptop for lighter gaming and everything else in between. And yet, I felt like I was missing something. Although my laptop is portable, it's still a lot larger than I would like to carry. And despite its great specs, I still found the long Windows boot times to inhibit spontaneous use. I wanted something ultra light and portable that I could tuck away in a large purse or small bag to take to a cafe to do some light browsing, gaming, writing, etc and not worry about damaging hard drives or losing personal files if stolen.

I've never really considered getting an Acer laptop--I never considered it to be a quality brand so I always steered away. But after trying out a bunch of different Chromebooks in multiple different stores, I found the built quality and responsiveness of this model to be head and shoulders above the rest (even more expensive ones). We'll see how this thing holds up over time, but after having it for a few days I can say it feels reliable and sturdy, no rattles etc.

Build quality and feel: This thing brings a smile to my face. For someone who was for so long bogged down by high-spec but unwieldy computers, this thing is charming, fun, and a delight to use. I prefer using this over my expensive computers! It feels rugged yet slim, with a quality-feeling plastic/aluminum case and more tapered square edges (which appeals to me over sharp aluminum edges). I just love the feel of this thing. And it seems rugged enough to take a little abuse (though I wouldn't want to try dropping it to see how it fares). I'd say it's a good option for kids or those who need something that can be tucked into a bag without fear. The screen hinges feel sturdy, too. I love how there are no fans to make noise. It doesn't get hot.

Sound: Speakers are located in on the front right and left sides as small indented slats. Sound is surprisingly good! I wasn't expecting to use this to play music much so but this is a pleasant surprise. Plus, it comes with a headphone jack that appears to also be a combined headphone/mic jack. I do find however that if placed on a pillow, the pillow may dampen some of the sound since the speakers are pretty near the bottom of the case. But I don't mind too much--you just need to adjust it slightly.

Keyboard and trackpad: THIS IS THE BEST TRACKPAD I'VE EVER USED. This is actually one of the main reasons I selected this one over the others. It's very smooth, accurate, and responsive. My trackpad on my HP laptop drives me absolutely crazy as it jumps around a lot and the click rocker often mistakes a left click for a right click. This one is so much better to use, and the surface is way smoother so my (clean) fingers don't drag...instead they gloss right over and the computer responds quickly and accurately. It is also equipped with finger gesture recognition so you can scroll up/down with two fingers, switch between tabs with a swipe of three fingers, etc. Makes everything I do a much better experience. I like the solid feel of the keyboard--perfect fit for me, though it's a bit narrow (but that's the nature of getting an ultra portable laptop). The keyboard tray doesn't give when pressed, so it feels solid on that end. No backlight on the keys which makes it harder to type at night, but I find the keys feel more solid/sturdy which is appealing to me.

Screen: I love the matte finish--no glare. Surprisingly good viewing angles. I find it sufficient and easy on my eyes (though people with failing vision may find it too small). It's not super high resolution but I find it completely fine for me, even when watching detailed, sci-fi movies. It definitely surpassed by expectations for this budget computer. Brightness can be cranked up high enough for anything I'd ever need. I appreciate the low impact on battery life.

Speed: The Chrome OS works very well on low-spec computers, and here it shines. This thing is fast enough for most of my needs. I appreciate how the Intel Celeron processor is low on battery consumption. Though don't expect to be able to run more than 10 tabs or so. I did experience a crash when I was streaming music and had other tabs open and was downloading music to the sd card I installed. But with only 2gb of RAM, I wasn't too surprised. It booted right back up. More RAM is always better, but at this price point it's fine.

Portability: I love that I can stop what I'm doing, close the lid, toss it in a bag and forget about it and not worry about spinning hard drives, battery consumption, etc. I open the lid and everything is back up in a jiffy. No waiting for Windows to load up again.

Overall appeal: Cheery, ultra-portable, ridiculously easy and pleasurable to use, long battery life, quick, and solid. I love it!! Would buy again and recommend to family.

Guys! best would be an underrated word to describe the product. First few impressions,

Merits:
1. Super quick boot time, actually 3-4 secs.
2. Extremely handy to use the keypad, I've seen many people talking about plugging an external mouse which I don't think is necessary. Just in case you don't know. Tap using 2 fingers simultaneously for 'right click', drag up or down using 2 fingers to scroll. Drag sideways left or right to switch between tabs using 2 fingers.
3. Browser and other apps are pretty quick and responsive. Tons in the Web store for download.
4. Word, Excel and PowerPoint are simple and you wouldn't feel alienated at all if you are a regular MS office user. You can literally speak to word app, which recognizes and translates into script seamlessly.
5. Battery - I've used YouTube with the built in speakers and it lasted for a wholly 8 hour straight. Trust me!

Demerits:
1. I bought a white one and the color is bright white unlike the silverish white and prone to become untidy soon.
2. Webcam, not much of a deal, slightly grainy but still good enough to disclose your identity for video calls.

I was very impressed by the screen. You will be hard-pressed to find a better screen on any Chromebook under $200. The viewing angles aren't as good as IPS screens on more expensive notebooks but it's far superior to the crap TN panels on most Chromebooks. The screen is matte so I have no problems with any reflections. I didn't notice any back light bleed on the display.

Battery life is VERY good. I managed to get around 7 to 8 hours with my use. Charges very quickly from 0 to 100% in under 90 minutes.

The N2840 processor loaded most pages quickly but had a hard time fluidly playing MP4 or MKV videos off of my USB flash drives. The faster Broadwell processor on my Dell Chromebook 13 had no problems with the same task.

I love the keyboard! I found it to be a pleasure to type on with great feedback from the keys.

The bottom line is that this is an amazing Chromebook for under $200. I would never recommend anything to you that I wouldn't use for myself and the screen alone is reason enough to strongly consider this for your first / next Chromebook.

You will not find a better chrome book at this price point, period. A chrome book should 1) Surf the web quickly, 2) Provide quality visual experience, and 3) Provide reasonable sound quality. And this machine does all this very well. But there is a fourth thing a chrome book should do and that is to provide a laptop experience without the expense and this unit accomplishes this too. With Bluetooth 4.0, Built-In HD Webcam, 1 - USB 3.0 Port, 1-USB 2.0 Port, 1 - HDMI Port... this machine gives you the connections you need to connect to a printer, and connect a USB flash drive for external data storage. I think you could even connect it to a big screen TV via HDMI port. Battery life is excellent and this machine is a superior product all around for under $200.00. Highly recommended!

Let me start off saying that I am a long time Mac user. I've only ever known my Mac, and I loved it dearly. It was more than I ever needed in a laptop, but it was time for a change (it was dying and falling apart on me). I've played around on a friends dell/windows (?) laptop before, and hated it ( not the desktop though). I just couldn't get used to the "feel" of it and the mouse touch pad drove me crazy. It seemed more complicated than my Macs mouse touch pad. So with my lack in laptop experience, I was a hesitant shopper. I researched what I could and this Acer Chromebook seemed to have good reviews and was in my price range! (I even posted some questions and got some very helpful answers from users here on amazon!) I bought the ~Intel Celeron N2840 2.16 GHz ~2 GB DDR3L SDRAM ~16 GB Internal Storage ~11.6-Inch HD IPS Screen, Intel HD Graphics ~Patterned Aluminum Cover, Google Chrome, Up to 9-hour battery life Chromebook (New) I've only been using this Chromebook for a few day's now (I'm actually writing this review on it right now), and I have to say I absolutely love it! I was worried about a memory so I picked up a SanDisk 32GB Class 4 SDHC Memory Card, Frustration-Free Packaging- SDSDB-032G-AFFP (Label May Change). I've been leaving it in my Chromebook without any problem. It almost perfectly lines up with the side of the chromebook. So as long as I'm not pushing in the sides, the SD card shouldn't accidentally be "clicked" out. I haven't used any memory yet other than saving a couple pictures (to set my wallpaper and my sign in picture). This Chromebook is lightweight and I can easily move it from room to room. There is no overheating/fan noise (and I've played around on it for HOURS and the underneath barely gets warm!). Offline I feel like, the battery would last up to 9 hours, but i've been playing online (not paying attention to how long) and I still don't worry about charging it until its there is about 10-15% life left, which is after hours of use! (and it only seems to take about 1 1/2 -2 hours to charge to full when I'm not on it). I make sure to take it off the charger after it is fully charged (I hear keeping any electronics on the charger after it is fully charged could decrease the battery usage/life and i'd rather be safe than sorry!) I love the keyboard, It's feels just like any regular keyboard. Minus the "cap lock" button. Which is the only button i'm getting used to not having (since I used to use it all the time) But love the search button, and how you can talk search too! (I'm still learning all the fun little things that come along with owning this little laptop!) The mouse touch pad has a nice feel and use to it. I like just "tapping" the Mouse pad allows you to "click" and that if you put pressure on the mouse pad, you can actually click (for highlighting, copy and pasting etc) I actually found that out by accident! (I was sad at first because I thought there was no way to highlight text or "right click" things - click with two fingers on the mouse pad!) Now to have full use of this Chromebook you DO need to have a Google account. You can either create one upon starting up the Chromebook or log into an existing account. There is not much to the start up paper, but it easy to figure things out just by playing around with the Chromebook! I think I covered about all I can think of! As of right now, I absolutely love this Chromebook and I do not regret ordering it! I've been able to surf the web, watch Youtube, play games (on websites Like facebook and gaiaonline), work on point to cash sites, and start up google documents without any problems! (all with good speeds too!) I've even messed around with the camera a bit! If anyone is looking for a case/pouch to go with your 11.6in chromebook, I bought one that suits my needs (and I can fit the charger in the other zipper too!) : Evecase Acer Chromebook 11.6-Inch CB3-111-C670 Neoprene Sleeve Pouch Case with Handle For Acer Chromebook 11 C670 / C720 / C710 Laptop PC - Green

I bought this after my 8 year old MacBook finally gave out on me (the battery had been having problems for years) and I have to say I love this! It's perfect for me - I am no longer in school and spend most of my computer time on the internet. I use Office Online for word processing and have had no issues with that. Google Drive is intuitively easy and makes organizing your files a snap. I can't honestly say there are any features not available on this unit that I miss - there are apps for nearly everything that I had been using on my MacBook and those that I haven't found replacements for I really don't find myself needing anyway. The unit itself is great for the price. The keyboard is not backlit, which my MacBook hadn't been either so that doesn't bother me. The unit is compact and light which means it's easy to take along with me if I need it. The battery lasts easily 8 hours and charges quickly. Boot up is extremely quick. The only issue I've had is occasionally losing my internet connection but that was a preexisting issue that comes from my router. All told, I really love this Chromebook. It's quick, portable, and does everything I need it to do. Highly recommended for those who need a computer for the basics.

It is fast and the charge lasts us all day.  When we do charge it, it charges very quickly and then goes and goes and goes.  The picture is clear and the sound is better than we had on our HP laptops.  Totally satisfied with these and probably will never get a laptop again.  With this replacement, who needs one?! Oh, plus the cost of 2 of these was still more than a hundred dollars less than  just one of our laptops 3 years ago. Right now we are printing off one of the laptops until our printer dies.  My husband rigged it so the chromebook and laptop are setup with the printer.  No big deal.  When the printer dies, it will be replaced with a cloud printer and that will simplify our lives even more.  Love this lightweight beauty!
Works great for Web browsing

My laptop was getting slower and hotter over time and decided to give this a try as I was increasingly using cloud-based computing.  First impressions: WOW!  Light, crisp, and very intuitive, as a Chrome user for a long time.  If you're heavy into word processing, powerpoints or need off-line capabilities, might have a transition period, but for browsing and cloud-based computing - it is awesome!

I got this on a whim from a local  retailer.  For the price its awesome for browsing and watching vids on the web.  For $170. its fast compared to more expensive tablets/laptops, rends pages better, plays vids good  Only downside is I wish I got one with a larger screen.  The battery life is also awesome!
Not sure if the laptop was damaged during shipping but it wouldn't work when I got it. It seemed like it was cheaply made anyways.

I wasn't sure I would be happy with a Cromebook. However having used it every day since I bought it a couple of weeks I love it.

I use it mostly on the web and it is fast and easy to use.

The size and weight are perfect for a mobile user. The screen is a good size. Big enough to read without being cumbersome.

Acer has produced a wonderful machine at a great price.
Love it!!! Highly recommend

Was rated one of the highest computers for teaching online and traveling . I wanted to like it so much however open the box and there is no cursor. Once I do tons of searching and trouble shooting I can enable cusor but not able to click. Resets and everything nothing allows me to click. This seems to be a hardware issue leaving abroad in a week for over a year this is my only computer to teach so cant refund. Looks like Ill have to get Bluetooth mouse. Which defeats purpose of portable computer. I wanted to love this computer but many users also said faulty trackpad on the Acer chromebook. Hoping wireless mouse I can fix settings, because Im stuck with it now.
We have not had any problems with this. Great purchase
Nice product, very good purchase.

I bought this in November on sale but it was for a graduation gift. It was opened in May 2018 and two weeks later the screen turned blue, green, then black and the thing shut down to never come back on again. I submitted for service repair under Amazon service request to get no response. I reached out again today to see if I will get a response. I also reached out directly to the manufacturer since it is under the 1 yr warranty still. I pray it can be repaired.
This was a birthday gift for my husband. He likes it for the most part, but he does have issues with it on occasion. It likes to freeze up and stall sometimes.
Great first computer for my grandkids.

I am a writer. i got this chromebook because it was cheap, and it was advertised (on a different site, not Amazon), as a computer that is great for writers. IT. IS. NOT. You cannot save documents to your desktop. The version of Office that is MILDLY compatible to chromebook is horrible. The best use for chromebook is to go onto amazon and order a new laptop from it.
Owned by 10 year old. Could be reason for short life. You should purchase extended warranty if owned by child. Price was good however $99- Black Friday Sale Nov 2017.

It worked great for 3 months then I went to turn it on and it wouldn't. I let it sit for a weekend plugged in and it suddenly turned on again. Worked well for a week, then the same issue. If I ever try to turn it on from powered all the way off, it refuses to turn on again for several days. It's confusing and frustrating and unreliable. I can't use it, and I'm just out the money now. Half the time plugging it in will not light up the battery light (I've used multiple cords, so it's not the charging cable) and the other half the lights do show. There's nothing I can tell for why it does this. A defective product with no help from Amazon to fix or replace.
